{{Year nav topic5|1612|literature}}
This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1612'''.
==Events== *[[January 6]] – [[Ben Jonson]]'s [[masque]] ''[[Love Restored]]'' is performed.<ref>{{cite book|first=E. K.|last=Chambers|authorlink=E. K. Chambers|title=The Elizabethan Stage|location=Oxford|publisher=Clarendon Press|year=1923|volume=3|page=387}}</ref> *[[January 12]] – The [[King's Men (playing company)|King's Men]] and [[Queen Anne's Men]] unite for the first of two English Court performances in January, with [[Thomas Heywood]]'s ''The Silver Age'' *[[January 13]] – The King's Men perform Heywood's ''The Rape of Lucrece''. *[[February 2]] – Queen Anne's Men return to court to play ''[[Greene's Tu Quoque]]''. *[[May 11]] – [[Shakespeare]] testifies in the [[Bellott v. Mountjoy]] lawsuit. *[[November 6]] – [[Henry Frederick, Prince of Wales]], eldest son and heir to King [[James I of England]], dies of [[typhoid fever]]. His coterie of followers, which included literary figures like [[Ben Jonson]] and [[John Selden]], are forced to seek other patrons.<ref>{{cite book|first=Roy|last=Strong|authorlink=Roy Strong|title=Henry, Prince of Wales and England's Lost Renaissance|location=London|publisher=Pimlico|year=1986}}</ref> *[[Thomas Shelton (translator)|Thomas Shelton]] publishes ''The History of the Valorous and Wittie Knight-Errant Don-Quixote of the Mancha'', the first translation of [[Miguel de Cervantes|Cervantes]]' novel ''[[Don Quixote]]'' (first part) into English (or any other language). *Death of Carlos Félix, the favourite son of [[Lope de Vega]].<ref>{{CathEncy|wstitle=Félix de Lope de Vega Carpio}}</ref> *The [[Accademia della Crusca]] publishes the first dictionary of the [[Italian language]]. *"Printers Bible": Some copies of the [[King James Version]] of the Bible printed in England this year contain an [[Bible errata|erratum]] with [[Psalm]] 119:161 reading "Printers have persecuted me without a cause" rather than "''Princes'' have persecuted me..."
==New books== *[[Traiano Boccalini]] – ''Ragguagli di Parnasso'' *[[John Brinsley the elder|John Brinsley]] – ''{{lang|la|Ludus literarius}}; or The Grammar Schoole'' *[[John Davies (poet)|John Davies]] – ''Discoverie of the True Causes why Ireland was never entirely subdued'' *[[John Davies of Hereford]] – ''The Picture of a Happy Man'' *[[Edward Grimeston]] ** ''The Generall Historie of Spaine'' (translated from French) ** ''The General History of the Magnificent State of Venice'' *[[Thomas Heywood]] – ''An Apology for Actors'' *[[Antonius Magirus]] – ''Koock-boeck ofte Familieren kevken-boeck'' *[[William Strachey]] - ''The Historie of Travaile Into Virginia Britannia'' *[[Francisco de Quevedo]] – ''La cuna y la sepultura''
==New drama== *[[George Chapman]] – ''[[The Widow's Tears]]'' published *[[Robert Daborne]] – ''[[A Christian Turn'd Turk]]'' published *[[Nathan Field]] – ''[[A Woman is a Weathercock]]'' published *[[Ben Jonson]] – ''[[Love Restored]]'' ([[masque]]) *[[John Webster]] – ''[[The White Devil]]'' published<ref name="Cassell's Chronology">{{cite book|last=Williams|first=Hywel|title=Cassell's Chronology of World History|location=London|publisher=Weidenfeld & Nicolson|year=2005|isbn=0-304-35730-8|pages=243–248}}</ref>
==Poetry== {{main|1612 in poetry}} * [[Michael Drayton]] – ''[[Poly-Olbion]]''<ref name="Cassell's Chronology"/> *[[Luis de Góngora]] – ''Fábula de Polifemo y Galatea (Fable of Polyphemus and Galatea)'' *Expanded edition of ''[[The Passionate Pilgrim]]'' *[[George Wither]] – Elegy on the death of [[Henry Frederick, Prince of Wales]]
==Births== *[[February 6]] – [[Antoine Arnauld]], French theologian and philosopher (died [[1694 in literature|1694]]) *[[February 7]] – [[Thomas Killigrew]], English dramatist (died [[1683 in literature|1683]]) *[[February 28]] – [[John Pearson (scholar)|John Pearson]], English theologian and scholar (died [[1686 in literature|1686]]) *[[March 4]] ''(bapt.)'' – [[Jan Vos (poet)|Jan Vos]], Dutch poet and dramatist (died [[1667 in literature|1667]]) *[[March 20]] – [[Anne Bradstreet]], née Dudley, English-born American poet (died [[1672 in literature|1672]]) *[[December 4]] – [[Samuel Butler (poet)|Samuel Butler]], English poet and satirist (died [[1680 in literature|1680]]) *''Unknown date'' – [[Edward King (British poet)|Edward King]], English poet (died [[1637 in literature|1637]]) *''Probable year of birth'' – [[John Rushworth]], English lawyer and historian (died [[1690 in literature|1690]])
==Deaths== *February – [[John Gerard]] (John Gerarde), English botanist and author of [[herbal]] (born c. 1545) *[[March 16]] – [[Thomas Holland (translator)|Thomas Holland]], English theologian and Bible translator (born [[1539 in literature|1539]]) *[[April 11]] – [[Emanuel van Meteren]], Flemish historian (born [[1535 in literature|1535]]) *[[July 29]] – [[Jacques Bongars]], French diplomat and scholar (born [[1554 in literature|1554]]) *[[August 4]] – [[Hugh Broughton]], English Biblical scholar (born [[1549 in literature|1549]]) *September – [[Giovanni de' Bardi]], Italian music theorist and critic (born [[1534 in literature|1534]]) *[[September 27]] – [[Piotr Skarga]] (Piotr Poweski), Polish hagiographer (born [[1536 in literature|1536]]) *[[October 7]] – [[Giovanni Battista Guarini]], Italian poet (born [[1538 in literature|1538]]) *[[November 20]] – Sir [[John Harington (writer)|John Harington]], English courtier, writer and inventor of flush toilet (born [[1560 in literature|1560]])
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:1612 books| ]] [[Category:Years in literature]] [[Category:Years of the 17th century in literature]]

{{refimprove|date=September 2013}} {{Year nav topic5|1743|literature|poetry}}
This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1743'''.
==Events== *[[Johann Elias Schlegel]] becomes secretary to an ambassador at the Danish court. *A [[legal deposit]] law requires a copy of every book printed in the [[Grand Duchy of Tuscany]] to be deposited in the [[National Central Library (Florence)|Magliabechiana library]] in [[Florence]].
==New books== ===Prose=== *[[William Rufus Chetwood]] – ''The Twins'' (prose fiction) *[[Henry Fielding]] – ''The Life of [[Jonathan Wild]] the Great'' in ''Miscellanies'', with ''A Journey from This World to the Next'' *[[Aaron Hill (writer)|Aaron Hill]] – ''The Fanciad'' *[[Benjamin Martin (lexicographer)|Benjamin Martin]] – ''A Course of Lectures in Natural and Experimental Philosophy, Geography, and Astronomy''<ref>First edition. [http://www.jarndyce.co.uk/online_catalogues/E-LIST1585-1752.pdf Retrieved 12 September 2017.]</ref> *[[Diego de Torres Villarroel]] – ''Vida''
===Drama=== *[[Charles Simon Favart]] – ''Le Coq du village'' *[[Henry Fielding]] – ''The Wedding-Day'' *[[John Gay]] – ''The Distress'd Wife'' *[[Voltaire]] – ''Mérope'' *[[William Shakespeare]] (ed. [[Sir Thomas Hanmer, 4th Baronet|Thomas Hanmer]]) – ''The Works of Shakespear''
===Poetry=== *[[Robert Blair (poet)|Robert Blair]] – ''[[The Grave (poem)|The Grave]]''<ref name=cocel>{{cite book|editor=Cox, Michael|title=The Concise Oxford Chronology of English Literature|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2004|isbn=0-19-860634-6}}</ref> *[[Samuel Boyse]] – ''Albion's Triumph'' *[[James Bramston]] (attributed) – ''The Crooked Six-pence'' *[[William Collins (poet)|William Collins]] – ''Verses Humbly Address'd to Sir Thomas Hanmer'' (related to Hanmer's edition of ''The Works of Shakespear'') *[[Philip Francis (translator)|Philip Francis]] – ''The Odes, Epodes, and Carmen Seculare of Horace'' *[[David Mallet (writer)|David Mallet]] – ''Poems on Several Occasions'' *[[Alexander Pope]] – ''[[The Dunciad|The New Dunciad]]'' (revised version)
===Non-fiction=== *[[Henry Baker (naturalist)|Henry Baker]] – ''The Microscope Made Easy'' *[[Henry St. John, 1st Viscount Bolingbroke]] – ''Remarks on the History of England'' (from ''The Craftsman'') *[[John Brown (essayist)|John Brown]] – ''Honour'' *[[Colley Cibber]] **''The Egotist; or, Colley Upon Cibber'' (many deprecations on [[Alexander Pope]]) **''A Second Letter from Mr. Cibber to Mr. Pope'' *[[Thomas Cooke (author)|Thomas Cooke]] – ''An Epistle to the Countess of Shaftesbury'' *[[Manuel da Assumpção]] – ''Vocabolario em idioma Bengalla, e Portuguez'' (Vocabulary of the Bengali Language and Portuguese) *[[Philip Doddridge]] – ''The Principles of the Christian Religion'' *[[Enrique Flórez]] – ''Clave historial con que se abre la puerta a la historia eclesiástica y política'' (''Clavis Historiae'') *[[Eliza Haywood]] – ''A Present for a Servant-Maid'' (conduct book for female servants, in the light of [[Samuel Richardson|Richardson's]] ''Pamela'') *[[William Stukeley]] – ''Abury: A temple of the British Druids'' *[[William Whitehead (English poet)|William Whitehead]] – ''An Essay on Ridicule''
==Births== *[[January 25]] – [[Friedrich Heinrich Jacobi]], German philosopher (died [[1819 in literature|1819]]) *[[February 14]] – [[Jane Bowdler]], English poet and essayist (died [[1784 in literature|1784]]) *[[March 4]] – [[Johann David Wyss]], Swiss novelist writing in German (died [[1818 in literature|1818]]) *[[March 14]] – [[Hannah Cowley]], English dramatist and poet (died [[1809 in literature|1809]]) *[[April 13]] – [[Thomas Jefferson]], American revolutionary and president (died [[1826 in literature|1826]] *[[June 20]] – [[Anna Laetitia Barbauld]], English poet (died [[1825 in literature|1825]]) *[[July 14]] – [[Gavrila Romanovich Derzhavin]], Russian lyric poet (died [[1816 in literature|1816]]) *[[July 30]] – [[Philip Yorke (antiquary)|Philip Yorke]], Welsh antiquary and genealogist (died [[1804 in literature|1804]]) *''Unknown date'' – [[Julien Louis Geoffroy]], French critic (died [[1814 in literature|1814]])
==Deaths== *[[April 4]] **[[Robert Ainsworth (lexicographer)|Robert Ainsworth]], English lexicographer (born [[1660 in literature|1660]]) **[[Daniel Neal]], English historian (born [[1678 in literature|1678]]) *[[April 29]] – [[Charles-Irénée Castel de Saint-Pierre]], French writer and thinker (born [[1658 in literature|1658]]) *[[May 6]] – [[Andrew Michael Ramsay]], Scottish biographer (born [[1686 in literature|1686]]) *[[August 1]] – [[Richard Savage (poet)|Richard Savage]], English poet (born c. 1697) *[[October 5]] – [[Henry Carey (writer)|Henry Carey]], English poet, composer, and dramatist (born [[1687 in literature|1687]]) *[[October 15]] – [[John Ozell]], English translator (date of birth not known)
==References== {{reflist}}
{{authoritycontrol}} {{DEFAULTSORT:1743 In Literature}} [[Category:1743 books| ]] [[Category:Years in literature]] [[Category:Years of the 18th century in literature]]

{{refimprove|date=July 2014}} {{Year nav topic5|1877|architecture}}
The year '''1877 in architecture''' involved some significant events.
==Buildings== [[File:Manchester Town Hall from Lloyd St.jpg|thumb|350px|[[Manchester Town Hall]], England]] * [[Galleria Vittorio Emanuele II]] (shopping arcade) in [[Milan]], designed by [[Giuseppe Mengoni]], is completed. * Galleria dell'Industria Subalpina in [[Turin]], designed by Pietro Carrera, is completed. * [[Manchester Town Hall]] in [[Manchester]], [[England]], designed by [[Alfred Waterhouse]], is completed. * [[Trinity Church (Boston)]] in the United States, designed by [[Henry Hobson Richardson]], is consecrated. * New railway stations for the [[North Eastern Railway (United Kingdom)]] are completed at [[York railway station|York]], largely designed by Thomas Prosser, and [[Middlesbrough railway station|Middlesbrough]], designed by William Peachey. * [[Maria Pia Bridge]] in [[Porto]], Portugal, built by [[Gustave Eiffel]], is completed. * Rebuilt [[Ardverikie House]] in [[Scotland]], designed by [[John Rhind]], is completed.<ref>{{cite web|title=History|url=http://www.ardverikie.com/history.htm|publisher=Ardverikie Estate Limited|accessdate=2014-07-05}}</ref>
==Events== * March 22 – [[Society for the Protection of Ancient Buildings]] established by [[William Morris]] and others meeting in [[Bloomsbury]], [[London]]. * [[Richard Norman Shaw]] appointed architect to [[Bedford Park, London]].
==Awards== *[[Royal Institute of British Architects|RIBA]] [[Royal Gold Medal]] – [[Charles Barry (junior)]].
==Births== * May 14 – [[Randall Wells]], English [[Arts and Crafts movement|Arts and Crafts]] architect (died [[1942 in architecture|1942]]) * June 12 – [[Johann Friedrich Höger]], German architect (died [[1949 in architecture|1949]]) * December 6 – [[:de:Paul Bonatz|Paul Bonatz]], German architect (died [[1956 in architecture|1956]])
==Deaths== * February 23 – [[Thomas Talbot Bury]], [[English people|English]] architect and [[lithographer]] (died [[1809 in architecture|1809]]) * May 8 – [[Edmund Sharpe]], English architect and architectural historian (born 1809) * October 8 – [[John Raphael Rodrigues Brandon]], English [[Gothic Revival architecture|Gothic Revival]] architect (born [[1817 in architecture|1817]])
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:1877 in arts|Arch]] [[Category:1877 works|Architecture]] [[Category:Years in architecture]] [[Category:19th-century architecture]]

revision.text:
{{Year nav topic5|1965|film|television|radio }} {{Yearsinfilm}} <!-- SIDEBAR NAV-BOX --> The year '''1965 in film''' involved some significant events, with ''[[The Sound of Music]]'' topping the U.S. box office.
==Events== * February 15 - [[George Stevens]]' production of ''[[The Greatest Story Ever Told]]'', a retelling of the account of [[Jesus Christ]], premieres in [[New York City, New York]]. It was such a flop with critics and audiences that its failure discouraged production of religious epics for many years. It is considered notable in the 21st century for its astonishing landscapes, powerful and provocative cinematography, [[Max von Sydow]]'s debut acting performance in an American film, and the final film performance of [[Claude Rains]]. * March 2 - The [[Rodgers and Hammerstein]] film adaptation of ''[[The Sound of Music (film)|The Sound of Music]]'', directed by [[Robert Wise]] and starring [[Julie Andrews]] and [[Christopher Plummer]], premieres. It quickly became a worldwide phenomenon and an instant classic. It successfully displaced ''[[Gone with the Wind (film)|Gone with the Wind]]'' to become, at the time, [[List of highest-grossing films in Canada and the United States#Adjusted for ticket-price inflation|the highest-grossing film of all-time]]. ''The Sound of Music'' is credited as the film that saved and restored [[Twentieth Century-Fox]] from bankruptcy after it suffered from extremely high production costs and low revenue of ''[[Cleopatra (1963 film)|Cleopatra]]'' two years prior. * July 1 - [[Blake Edwards]]'s epic comedy ''[[The Great Race]],'' starring [[Tony Curtis]], [[Jack Lemmon]], [[Natalie Wood]], [[Peter Falk]], and [[Keenan Wynn]], premieres. Initially a flop with critics and audiences, some do admire Edwards' direction, the acting by its ensemble cast, [[Henry Mancini]]'s music and its climactic pie fight. * December 22 - [[David Lean]]'s film adaptation of [[Boris Pasternak]]'s ''[[Doctor Zhivago (film)|Doctor Zhivago]]'', starring [[Omar Sharif]], [[Julie Christie]], [[Rod Steiger]], and [[Alec Guinness]], premieres and, like ''The Sound of Music'', quickly became a worldwide phenomenon. Its moral story and message of a love and human spirit that defied the communist Soviet Union have made the film a true classic with critics and audiences. It was included among top films by the [[AFI's 100 Years...100 Movies|American Film Institute]]. In a decade of very difficult times for its studio, ''Zhivago'' became the most successful and acclaimed [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] film since ''[[How the West Was Won (film)|How the West Was Won]];'' it was the greatest MGM film since ''[[Ben-Hur (1959 film)|Ben-Hur]]''.
==Top-grossing films (U.S.)== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Rank || Title || Studio || Gross |- | 1. | ''[[The Sound of Music (film)|The Sound of Music]]'' | [[20th Century Fox]] | '''$138,700,000'''<ref name="Block & Wilson">{{cite book |editor1-last=Block|editor1-first=Alex Ben|editor2-last=Wilson|editor2-first=Lucy Autrey|year=2010|title=George Lucas's Blockbusting: A Decade-By-Decade Survey of Timeless Movies Including Untold Secrets of Their Financial and Cultural Success|publisher=[[HarperCollins]]|isbn=9780061778896|ref=harv}} *''The Sound of Music'': p.434. $138.7 million (Initial Release Domestic Box office)</ref> |- | 2. |''[[Doctor Zhivago (1965 film)|Doctor Zhivago]]'' | [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] | '''Unknown'''{{NoteTag|The first-run gross of ''Doctor Zhivago'' is unknown. However, in terms of [[gross rental]] (the distributor's cut of the gross) it earned $43 million, second only to ''The Sound of Music''{{'}}s $72 million and over fifty percent more than the $27 million earned by ''Thunderball'' in third-place.<ref>{{cite book |last=Finler |first=Joel Waldo |year=2003 |title=The Hollywood Story |publisher=Wallflower Press |isbn=978-1-903364-66-6 |page=359}}</ref> Its lifetime box-office gross—including revenue from re-releases—totals $111.7 million.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=doctorzhivago.htm|website=[[Box Office Mojo]]|title=Doctor Zhivago, Box Office Information|accessdate=January 22, 2013}}</ref>}} |- | 3. |''[[Thunderball (film)|Thunderball]]'' | [[United Artists]] | '''$63,595,658'''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=thunderball.htm|website=[[Box Office Mojo]]|title=Thunderball, Box Office Information|accessdate=January 22, 2013}}</ref> |- | 4. | ''[[Those Magnificent Men in their Flying Machines]]'' | 20th Century Fox | '''$31,111,111'''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/1965/0TMMF.php|website=The Numbers|title=Those Magnificent Men in their Flying Machines, Box Office Information|accessdate=January 22, 2013}}</ref> |- | 5. | ''[[That Darn Cat! (1965 film)|That Darn Cat!]]'' | [[Walt Disney Pictures|Walt Disney Productions]] | '''$28,068,222'''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/1965/0THTD.php|website=The Numbers|title=That Darn Cat, Box Office Information|accessdate=January 22, 2013}}</ref> |- | 6. |''[[The Great Race]]'' | [[Warner Bros.]] | '''$25,333,333'''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/1965/0GRAC.php|website=The Numbers|title=The Great Race, Box Office Information|accessdate=January 22, 2013}}</ref> |- | 7. | ''[[Cat Ballou]]'' | [[Columbia Pictures]] | '''$20,666,667'''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/1965/0CABA.php|website=The Numbers|title=Cat Ballou, Box Office Information|accessdate=January 22, 2013}}</ref> |- | 8. | ''[[What's New Pussycat?]]'' | United Artists | '''$18,820,000'''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/1965/0WNPC.php|website=The Numbers|title=What's New Pussycat?, Box Office Information|accessdate=January 22, 2013}}</ref> |- | 9. | ''[[Shenandoah (film)|Shenandoah]]'' | [[Universal Pictures]] | '''$17,268,889'''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/1965/00250.php|website=The Numbers|title=Shenandoah, Box Office Information|accessdate=January 22, 2013}}</ref> |- | 10. | ''[[Von Ryan's Express]]'' | 20th Century Fox | '''$17,111,111'''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/1965/0VREX.php|website=The Numbers|title=Von Ryan's Express, Box Office Information|accessdate=January 22, 2013}}</ref> |}
{{NoteFoot}}
==Awards== '''[[38th Academy Awards|Academy Awards]]:'''
:[[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]]: '''''[[The Sound of Music (film)|The Sound of Music]]''''' - Argyle Enterprises, Twentieth Century-Fox :[[Academy Award for Directing|Best Director]]: '''[[Robert Wise]]''' - ''The Sound of Music'' :[[Academy Award for Best Actor|Best Actor]]: '''[[Lee Marvin]]''' - ''[[Cat Ballou]]'' :[[Academy Award for Best Actress|Best Actress]]: '''[[Julie Christie]]''' - ''[[Darling (1965 film)|Darling]]'' :[[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor|Best Supporting Actor]]: '''[[Martin Balsam]]''' - ''[[A Thousand Clowns (film)|A Thousand Clowns]]'' :[[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress|Best Supporting Actress]]: '''[[Shelley Winters]]''' - ''[[A Patch of Blue]]'' :[[Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film|Best Foreign Language Film]]: '''''[[The Shop on Main Street]]''''' (''Obchod na korze''), directed by [[Ján Kadár]] and [[Elmar Klos]], Czechoslovakia
'''[[BAFTA]] Film Awards:'''
:Best Film from Any Source: '''''[[My Fair Lady]]''''' :Best British Film: '''''[[The Ipcress File (film)|The Ipcress File]]'''''
'''[[23rd Golden Globe Awards|Golden Globe Awards]]:'''
:<u>'''Drama:'''</u> :[[Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Drama|Best Picture]]: '''''[[Doctor Zhivago (1965 film)|Doctor Zhivago]]''''' :[[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Drama|Best Actor]]: '''[[Omar Sharif]]''' - ''Doctor Zhivago'' :[[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Drama|Best Actress]]: '''[[Samantha Eggar]]''' - ''[[The Collector]]''
:<u>'''Musical or comedy:'''</u> :[[Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy|Best Picture]]: '''''The Sound of Music''''' :[[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy|Best Actor]]: '''Lee Marvin''' - ''Cat Ballou'' :[[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy|Best Actress]]: '''[[Julie Andrews]]''' - ''The Sound of Music''
:<u>'''Other'''</u> :[[Golden Globe Award for Best Director – Motion Picture|Best Director]]: '''[[David Lean]]''' - ''Doctor Zhivago''
'''[[Palme d'Or]] (Cannes Film Festival):''' :'''''[[The Knack ...and How to Get It]]''''', directed by [[Richard Lester]], United Kingdom
'''[[Golden Lion]] (Venice Film Festival):''' :'''''[[Vaghe stelle dell'Orsa]]''''' (''Sandra of a Thousand Delights''), directed by [[Luchino Visconti]], Italy
'''[[Berlin Film Festival|Golden Bear]] (Berlin Film Festival):''' :'''''[[Alphaville, a Strange Adventure of Lemmy Caution|Alphaville]]''''', directed by [[Jean-Luc Godard]], France / Italy

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} {{Use Australian English|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox film | name = Babakiueria | image = BabaKiueria title card.jpg | image_size = | border = | alt = | caption = | director = [[Don Featherstone (filmmaker)|Don Featherstone]] | producer = [[Julian Pringle]] | writer = | screenplay = [[Geoffrey Atherden]] | story = | based on = <!-- {{based on|title of the original work|writer of the original work}} --> | narrator = | starring = {{plainlist| * [[Michelle Torres (actor)|Michelle Torres]] * [[Bob Maza]] * Kevin Smith}} | music = Peter Crosbie | cinematography = Julian Penney | editing = Michael Honey | studio = | distributor = | released = 1986 | runtime = 29:00 | country = [[Australia]] | language = English | budget = | gross = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Babakiueria''''' (also known under the video-title '''''Babakiueria (Barbeque Area)''''') is a 1986 [[Australian]] [[satire|satirical]] film on relations between [[Indigenous Australians|Aboriginal Australians]] and [[European Australian|Australians of European descent]].
==Synopsis== ''Babakiueria'' revolves around a role-reversal, whereby it is Aboriginal Australians who have invaded and [[colonization|colonised]] the fictitious country of Babakiueria, a land that has long been inhabited by white natives, the Babakiuerians.
The opening scene depicts a group of Aboriginal Australians in military uniforms coming ashore in a land they have not previously been to. In this land, they discover a number of European Australians engaged in stereotypical European Australian activities. The Aboriginal Australian explorers approach the group and the expedition's leader asks them, "What do you call this place"? One of the Europeans replies, "Er... '[[Barbecue]] Area'".
After around 200 years of Aboriginal occupation, white Australians have become a minority. Aboriginal people have assumed power, taken all of the available land and have mostly confined whites to suburban [[ghettos]]. They are expected to follow the laws and customs of the colonisers and their lifestyle is seen through the patronizing eyes of the majority culture. The latest [[wikt:manifest|manifestation]] of this is in a 'documentary' presented by Duranga Manika ([[Michelle Torres (actor)|Michelle Torres]]).<ref name="abc">{{cite web|url=http://abccommercial.com/librarysales/program/babakiueria |title="Babakiueria" |publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] |accessdate=21 December 2014 }}</ref><ref name="ra">{{cite web|url=https://radio.adelaide.edu.au/babakiueria-a-satirical-tale-of-the-invasion-of-the-white-peoples-land/ |title=""BabaKiueria" – a satirical tale of the invasion of the white people’s land" |publisher=[[Radio Adelaide]] |date=26 January 2014 |accessdate=21 December 2014 }}</ref><ref name="UMD">{{cite web|url=http://www.d.umn.edu/cla/faculty/troufs/anth1604/video/Babakiueria.html |last=Roufs |first=Timothy |title="Babakiueria" |publisher=[[University of Minnesota Duluth]] |date=12 March 2012 |accessdate=21 December 2014 }}</ref>
The remainder of the film follows Duranga Manika as she observes how white people are disempowered through poverty, are treated unfairly by the police - often with [[Police brutality|brutality]] and indifference, experience arbitrary dispossession, government inaction on white issues, white [[tokenism]], [[Stolen Generation|white children being taken from their families]] only to be taught the values of the majority culture and white people being relocated because the government needs their home for "something". White people are now often characterized by society and in the media as lazy, unintelligent and untrustworthy and anyone who protests about the current circumstances is labeled as a 'troublemaker'. White rituals and cultural values are derided and dismissed as violent and meaningless. The Babakiuerian government's [[paternalistic]] policies are defended by Wagwan, the Minister for White Affairs ([[Bob Maza]]) who was based on the then [[Premier of Queensland]], [[Joh Bjelke-Petersen|Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen]].<ref name="abc" /><ref name="ra" /><ref name="UMD" /><ref name="NFSA">{{cite web|url=http://aso.gov.au/titles/shorts/babakiueria/notes/ |last=Matthews |first=Kate |title="Babakiueria (1986)" |publisher=[[National Film and Sound Archive]] |accessdate=21 December 2014 }}</ref><ref name="Cambridge">{{cite web|url=https://www.cambridge.edu.au/education/files/5313/8724/1953/Julius_Caesar.pdf |title="Cambridge Checkpoints HSC Advanced English" |publisher=[[Cambridge University]] |accessdate=21 December 2014 }}</ref>
The inversion of reality in ''Babakiueria'' highlights the unfairness of Australia's past and present Aboriginal policies and the entrenched racism in society. This subversion of normality allows viewers to see what is wrong when one group tries to control and dominate another and questions the fairness of the current power structure in Australia.<ref name="Cambridge" />
==Production== Much of ''Babakiueria'' was filmed on location, including the Anzac March and the 'Ritual of Violence' ([[Australian Football League|AFL]] Game). It was screened in the [[Australian Museum]] for many years.<ref name="NFSA" />
==Impact and Reception== ''Babakiueria'' has been used at times to educate police officers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.creativespirits.info/resources/movies/babakiueria-barbecue-area |title="Babakiueria ("Barbecue Area")" |publisher=www.CreativeSpirits.info |accessdate=21 December 2014 }}</ref>
After it was screened at the Message Sticks Festival in 2012, Mahjid Heath noted that "issues we were struggling with in the early 80's are still relevant and still define the political and national discourses today."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/indigenous/stories/s3471253.htm |last=Heath |first=Mahjid |title="Message Sticks Festival 2012" |publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] |date=3 April 2012 |accessdate=21 December 2014 }}</ref>
==Cast== * [[Michelle Torres (actor)|Michelle Torres]] - (Presenter Duranga Manika) * [[Bob Maza]] - (Wagwan - Government Minister) * Kevin Smith - (Police Superintendent) * [[Tony Barry]] - (Father (Mr. Smith)) * [[Cecily Polson]] - (Mother) * Kelan Angel - (Son) * Marguerita Haynes - (Daughter) * Garry Williams - (Explorer) * Soul Beliear - (Police Sergeant #1) * Terry Reid - (Police Sergeant #2) * Athol Compton - (Newsreader) * Kati Edwards - (Grandmother) * Yvonne Shipley - (Wealthy Woman)
==Awards== {| class="wikitable" <!-- to use sortable requires eliminating all use of rowspan --> |- ! Ceremony ! Year ! Result |- | [[United Nations Association of Australia#Media Peace Awards|United Nations Media Peace Prize]] | 1987 | {{won}}<ref name="NFSA" /><ref>[http://www.alsnswact.org.au/pages/films/ BabaKiueria at the ''Films''-Section of the Aboriginal Legal Service (NSW/ACT) Ltd. Homepage.] Retrieved 19 November 2012.</ref> |}
==Broadcasting== {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! Country ! Network(s)/Station(s) |- | {{flag|Australia}} || [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]] |}
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== *{{Imdb title|id=0166032|title=Babakiueria}} *[https://itunes.apple.com/au/tv-season/babakiueria-barbeque-area/id658716604 Babakiueria (Barbeque Area)] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oUMpPgMGCe8 Watch full movie] on [[YouTube]].

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contributions/2607:FCC8:AB4F:F700:782F:DB4B:4ED0:17D1|2607:FCC8:AB4F:F700:782F:DB4B:4ED0:17D1]] ([[User talk:2607:FCC8:AB4F:F700:782F:DB4B:4ED0:17D1|talk]]): not providing a [[WP:RS|reliable source]] ([[WP:CITE]], [[WP:RS]]) ([[WP:HG|HG]]) (3.4.4)
revision.text:
{{other uses}} {{distinguish|Bixie}} {{Infobox Chinese |title = '''Bixi''' |float = <!-- left|right|none (Default float position is right) --> |collapse = <!-- yes|no --> |pic = Bixi_in_Harvard_University_-_IMG_8960.JPG |piccap = The [[Harvard Bixi]], donated by its [[Republic of China (1912-1949)|Chinese]] alumni |picsize = |pictooltip = Sculpted {{circa|lk=no|1810}}, donated 1936 |t = {{linktext|贔|屭}} |s = {{linktext|赑|屃}} |p = Bìxì |w = Pi-hsi <!-- First alternative name --> |altname = '''Pa-hsia Dragon''' |c2 = {{linktext|霸|下}} |p2 = Bàxià |w2 = Pa-hsia <!-- Second alternative name --> |altname3 = '''guifu''' |t3 = {{linktext|龜|趺}} |s3 = {{linktext|龟|趺}} |l3 = turtle tablets |p3 = guīfū |w3 = kuei-fu |kanji = 贔屓 |hiragana = ひいき |romaji = Hīki |qn = đá rùa |chuhan = 石龜 }} '''Bixi''', or '''Bi Xi''' ({{zh|w='''''Pi-hsi'''''}}), is a figure from [[Chinese mythology]]. One of the [[9 sons of the dragon|9 sons]] of the [[Dragon King]], he is depicted as a [[Chinese dragon|dragon]] with the shell of a [[turtle]]. Stone [[Chinese sculpture|sculptures]] of Bixi have been used in [[Chinese culture]] for centuries as a decorative [[plinth]] for commemorative [[stele]]s and tablets,<ref>{{citation|last=Welch|first= Patricia Bjaaland|title=Chinese Art|publisher= Tuttle|year= 2008|isbn=0-8048-3864-X|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5sgO9BuZQSEC&pg=PA122|pages=122–123}}</ref> particularly in the [[Chinese funerary art|funerary complexes]] of its later [[List of rulers of China|emperors]] and to commemorate important events, such as an imperial visit or the anniversary of a [[Second Sino-Japanese War|World War II]] victory. They are also used at the bases of bridges and archways.<ref>Roberts, Jeremy. ''Chinese Mythology, A to Z'', [https://books.google.com/books?id=b40pj5iWNf0C&pg=PT61 p. 61. "Dragon's Nine Sons"]. 2nd ed. Chelsea House (New York), 2010. Accessed 22 November 2013.</ref> Sculptures of Bixi are traditionally rubbed for good luck, which can cause conservation issues.<ref>"[http://phaply.net.vn/van-hoa-phap-ly/van-mieu-quoc-tu-giam-ha-noi-82-bia-tien-si-can-duoc-bao-ve-nghiem-ngat.html Văn Miếu – Quốc Tử Giám – Hà Nội: 82 bia Tiến sĩ cần được bảo vệ nghiêm ngặt]". ''Pháplý Online'', 30 November 2011. Accessed 22 Nov 2013. {{vi icon}}</ref> They can be found throughout [[East Asian culture|East Asia]] in [[Japan]], [[Korea]], [[Vietnam]], [[Mongolia]], and even the [[Russian Far East]].
==History== [[File:LugouQiao-Qianlong-bridge-rebuilding-stele-CIMG3609.JPG|thumb|left|upright|A dragon-headed ''bixi'' with a stele in memory of the [[Qianlong Emperor]]'s rebuilding of the [[Marco Polo Bridge]], [[Beijing]], {{circa|lk=no|1785}}]] The tradition of tortoise-mounted stelae originated no later than early 3rd century (late [[Han dynasty]]). According to the 1957 survey by Chêng Tê-k'un (鄭徳坤), <!-- there is [[:de:Zheng Dekun]] already.... --> the earliest extant tortoise-borne stele is thought to be the one at the tomb of Fan Min (樊敏), in [[Lushan County, Sichuan|Lushan County]], [[Ya'an]], [[Sichuan]].<ref name=cheng>{{citation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MSA9AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA144 |page=144 |title=Archaeological studies in Szechwan |last=Chêng|first=Tê-kun |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=1957}}. The author's name would be spelled Zheng Dekun in Pinyin.</ref> [[Victor Segalen]] had earlier identified the stele as a [[Han dynasty]] monument; present-day authors agree, usually giving it the date of 205 AD.<ref name=seg68>{{harvnb|Segalen|1995|pp=68–69}}</ref><ref>{{citation|first=Robert E. |last=Harrist|publisher=University of Washington Press |year=2008 |title=The landscape of words: stone inscriptions from early and medieval China |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=plGOAAAAMAAJ | page=72}} (snippet view only on Google Books)</ref><ref>{{citation|title=The Chinese spirit road : the classical tradition of stone tomb statuary |last=Paludan|first= Ann|authorlink=Ann Paludan |publisher= Yale University Press|year= 1991|isbn= 0-300-04597-2|pages=50–51}}</ref> The stele has a rounded top with a dragon design in [[low relief]] - a precursor to the "two intertwined dragons" design that was very common on such steles even in the Ming and Qing Dynasties, over a thousand years later.<ref name=cheng/><ref>[http://www.scdms.com/lineArticleAction.do?method=showLineDetail&lineid=34910 雅安汉源九襄石牌坊、青溪古镇、金钟山、芦山龙门洞、飞仙关、灵鹫山五日游] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716013347/http://www.scdms.com/lineArticleAction.do?method=showLineDetail&lineid=34910 |date=July 16, 2011 }} (A Ya'an tourist trip description, with the photos from the "Fan Min Que (Gate Towers) and Sculptures" site (樊敏阙及石刻), including the present-day condition of the Fan Min stele, in a new gazebo</ref>
In the collection of the [[Nanjing Museum]] there is a ''[[hunping]]'' funerary jar, dating to 272 AD, with a miniature architectural composition on top, depicting, among other objects, a tortoise carrying a stele erected by the [[Jin dynasty (265–420)|Jin dynasty]] governor of [[Changsha]] in honor of a local dignitary.<ref>{{citation|first=Stanley K. |last=Abe|publisher=University of Chicago Press |year=2002|isbn=0-226-00044-3|title=Ordinary images |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=q7mSgzODyKMC&pg=PA72|pages=71–72}}</ref>
Perhaps the best known extant early example of the genre is the set of four stele-bearing tortoises at the mausoleum of [[Xiao Xiu]] (475-518), who was the younger brother of the first [[Liang dynasty]] emperor [[Emperor Wu of Liang|Wu]] (Xiao Yan), near [[Nanjing]].<ref>Angela Falco Howard, Li Song, Wu Hung, Yang Hong, «[https://books.google.com/books?id=PGuPsNCaJdwC Chinese Sculpture]». Yale University Press and Foreign Languages Press, 2006. {{ISBN|0-300-10065-5}}. Pp. 163—165; photo in Fig. 2.63</ref><ref>{{citation|first=Albert E. |last=Dien|publisher=Yale University Press |year=2007|isbn=0-300-07404-2 |title=Six dynasties civilization|series=Early Chinese civilization series |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=0zp6iMZoqt0C&pg=PA190 |page=190 }} A reconstruction of the original form of the ensemble is shown in Fig. 5.19.</ref><ref>[http://www.jllib.org.cn/ffy/nclmsksy/xiaoxiumusk.htm 梁安成康王萧秀墓石刻] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019220014/http://www.jllib.org.cn/ffy/nclmsksy/xiaoxiumusk.htm |date=2013-10-19 }} (Sculptures at the Tomb of Xiao Xiu) {{zh icon}} (description and modern photos)</ref>
The ''bixi'' tradition flourished during the [[Ming dynasty|Ming]] and [[Qing dynasty|Qing dynasties]]. The Ming founder, the [[Hongwu Emperor]], in the first year after the dynasty had been proclaimed (1368), adopted regulations, allowing tortoise-based funerary tablets to the [[Mandarin square|higher ranks]] of the [[Chinese nobility|nobility]] and the [[Mandarin (bureaucrat)|mandarinate]]. He tightened the rules in 1396, leaving only the highest nobility (those of the ''gong'' and ''hou'' ranks) and the officials of the [[mandarin square|top 3 ranks]] eligible for ''bixi''-based stelae. The type of [[Chinese dragon|dragons]] crowning the tortoise-born stele, and the type and number of other statuary at the tomb site, were prescribed by the same regulations as well.<ref name=deGroot2>{{citation |publisher=Brill Archive |year=1892a|first=Jan Jakob Maria |last=de Groot |title=The Religious System of China |volume=II |url=https://archive.org/stream/religioussystem01groogoog#page/n105/mode/1up |pages=451–452 }}.</ref>
[[File:Minzu-zhengqi-haoran-changcun-Bixi-3565.jpg|thumb|A modern (1995) monument in Beijing]] At the Hongwu Emperor's [[Ming Xiaoling Mausoleum|own mausoleum]], a huge ''bixi'' holding the so-called ''Shengde'' stele welcomes visitors at the Sifangcheng pavilion at the entrance of the mausoleum complex. Three centuries later (1699), the [[Kangxi Emperor]] of the Qing dynasty visited Nanjing and contributed another tortoise, with a stele praising the founder of the Ming, comparing him to the founders of the great Tang and Song dynasties of the past.<ref name=pd2003>[http://www.people.com.cn/GB/paper447/9409/871387.html 明孝陵两大“碑石之谜”被破解] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121018052502/http://www.people.com.cn/GB/paper447/9409/871387.html |date=2012-10-18 }} (Solving the two great riddles of the Ming Xiaoling's stone tablets). ''People's Daily'', 2003-06-13. Quote regarding the Kangxi's stele text and its meaning: "清朝皇帝躬祀明朝皇帝 ... 御书“治隆唐宋”（意思是赞扬朱元璋的功绩超过了唐太宗李世民、宋高祖赵匡胤）"; regarding the dimensions of the stele and its tortoise: "康熙御碑孝陵碑殿中部主碑，是清康熙三十八年（1699年）由康熙皇帝爱新觉罗·玄烨所立，高3.85米，宽1.42米，上阴刻楷书“治隆唐宋”4字，字径0.68米，碑座为石制龟趺，高1.06米。"</ref><ref>[http://www.orientalarchitecture.com/china/nanjing/xiaoling-tomb_gallery.php?p=xiaoling-tomb30.jpg Photo and description of the Kangxi's stele]. The inscription is interpreted as "His reign was as glorious as that of the Tang and Song"</ref>
The Hongwu Emperor's tortoise tradition was continued by the later Ming and Qing emperors, [[Imperial Tombs of the Ming and Qing Dynasties|whose mausoleums]] are usually decorated by ''bixi''-born steles as well.
Even the self-declared emperor [[Yuan Shikai]] was posthumously honored with a ''bixi''-based stele in [[Anyang]],<ref>[http://www.aynews.net.cn/jray/ShowArticle.asp?ArticleID=3736 洹园里的破嘴龟] (The tortoise with a broken mouth in Huanyuan Park) {{zh icon}}</ref> as was the [[Republic of China (1912–1949)|Republic of China]] Premier [[Tan Yankai]] (1880–1930), whose stele near [[Nanjing]]'s [[Linggu Temple]] had its inscription erased after the Communist Revolution.
Occasionally, a foreign head of state was honored with a ''bixi'' as well, as it happened to the sultan of [[Brunei]] [[Abdul Majid Hassan]], who died during his visit to China in 1408. The [[Tomb of the King of Boni|sultan's grave]], with a suitably royal ''bixi''-based monument, was discovered in Yuhuatai District south of [[Nanjing]] in 1958.<ref>Rozan Yunos, [http://www.bt.com.bn/en/life/2008/11/09/the_brunei_sultan_who_died_in_china "The Brunei Sultan who died in China"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090319185326/http://www.bt.com.bn/en/life/2008/11/09/the_brunei_sultan_who_died_in_china |date=March 19, 2009 }} The Brunei Times, 9.11.2008</ref>
After an [[Nestorian Christian|ancient Christian stele]] was unearthed in [[Xi'an]] in 1625, it, too, was put on the back of a tortoise. In 1907, this so-called [[Nestorian Stele]] was moved to the [[Stele Forest]] Museum along with its tortoise.<ref>{{citation|first=Michael |last=Keevak| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SCsCcij1S4AC |title=The Story of a Stele: China's Nestorian Monument and Its Reception in the West, 1625-1916 |isbn=962-209-895-9|year= 2008|pages=5–6, 105, 117 (Fig 38)}}. The first two images reproduced in Keevak's book had appeared earlier in Henri Havret (1848-1901), [https://archive.org/details/lastlechrtienne01havrgoog ''La stele chrétienne de Si-ngan fou'' (part 1)], ''Variétés sinologiques'' No. 7, Paris, 1895 (near the front cover, and page 139, respectively). As Havret comments (p. 142), looking at the early drawings it's rather easy to mistake the tortoise for a "horrible bat"!</ref><ref>See modern [https://www.flickr.com/photos/chinaencounters/2722082168/ photos of the stele on Flickr.com], complete with the same tortoise</ref>
These days, long-lost bixi continue to be unearthed during archaeological excavations and construction work. Among the most remarkable finds is the discovery of a huge 1200-year-old in [[Zhengding]] ([[Hebei]] Province) in June 2006. The stone turtle is 8.4 m long, 3.2 m wide, and 2.6 m tall, and weighs 107 tons. It has since been moved to Zhengding's [[Kaiyuan Temple (Zhengding)|Kaiyuan Temple]].<ref>[http://www.zd.gov.cn/WebSite/Info.aspx?ModelId=1&Id=2171 正定开元寺] (Zhengding's Kaiyuan Temple), 2014-12-22</ref>
==Outside China== [[File:National Museum Vietnamese History 65 (cropped).jpg|thumb|The Vinh Lang stele from [[Lê Lợi]]'s mausoleum, erected in the 6th year of Thuận Thiên reign (1433)]] [[File:ThienMuTurtle2001.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Turtle in [[Thien Mu Pagoda]], [[Hue, Vietnam]], 1715<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=ZHn_8ihziN8C&pg=PA70 Lonely Planet Guide, Vietnam, 2006. p. 70]</ref>]] The concept of a tortoise-borne, dragon-crowned stele was early adopted by China's northern neighbors. The earliest extant monument of the [[Göktürks|Turkic Kaganate]] - the so-called "Bugut Stele" of the late 6th century from [[Arkhangai Province]] in western [[Mongolia]] with a [[Sogdian language|Sogdian]] and (most likely) [[Sanskrit]] inscription was installed on a stone tortoise. It is now in the provincial capital, [[Tsetserleg (city)|Tsetserleg]].<ref name=bugut>[http://irq.kaznpu.kz/index.php?mod=1&tid=1&oid=2&lang=e The Tatpar (Kutlug) kagan memorial complex, 581-582]</ref><ref name=alyilmaz>Dr. Cengiz Alyilmaz, [http://www.transoxiana.org/Eran/Articles/alyilmaz.html On the Bugut Inscription and Mausoleum Complex]. Ēran ud Anērān: Studies presented to Boris Ilich Marshak on the Occasion of His 70th Birthday. Compareti, Raffetta, Scarcia - Editors. Electronic Version (October 2003)</ref> According to the Turkish researcher Cengiz Alyilmaz, it was the design of this stele that influenced the builders of the important 8th-century stelae with [[Old Turkic script|Old Turkic]] inscriptions, many of which also stood on tortoises.<ref name=alyilmaz/><ref>N.Bazylkhan [http://irq.kaznpu.kz/index.php?lang=e&mod=1&tid=1 The Orhon Inscriptions]</ref> Among them, the most accessible one is probably [[Bayanchur Khan]]'s (Eletmish Bilge Kağan)'s [[Tariat inscriptions|Terhin-Gol stele]] (753 AD), now in the Mongolian Academy of Sciences in [[Ulan Bator]].<ref>[http://irq.kaznpu.kz/index.php?mod=1&tid=1&oid=24&lang=e Inscription El etmish Bilge kagan (Tariat // Terh)]</ref>
Later, the [[Jurchen people|Jurchen]] [[Jin dynasty (1115-1234)]] and the [[Mongol]] [[Yuan dynasty]] erected tortoise-based monuments as well, some of which have been preserved in Russia's [[Ussuriysk]] and Mongolia's [[Karakorum]].
In Japan, this form of tortoise-supported stele is found primarily at the graves of prominent [[Kamakura period]] (1185–1333) figures, especially in the city of [[Kamakura, Kanagawa|Kamakura]]. Another large collection of tortoise-borne stelae, spanning 17th through 19th centuries, can be seen at the cemetery of the [[Tottori Domain]] ''[[daimyō]]'' outside [[Tottori, Tottori|Tottori]]. Otherwise, the form does not seem to have been particularly popular in earlier or later times.
In Korea, tortoise-borne stelae are known already during the [[Three Kingdoms of Korea]] period (e.g., the Tombstone of King [[Muyeol of Silla]], erected 661).<ref>[http://www.cha.go.kr/korea/heritage/search/Culresult_Db_View.jsp?VdkVgwKey=11,00250000,37 경주 태종무열왕릉비(慶州 太宗武烈王陵碑)] (Includes photos of Korean monuments) {{ko icon}}</ref> Monuments of this type have been preserved from the later [[Goryeo]] dynasty as well, such as the [[Stele of Bongseon Honggyeongsa]] (1026).<ref>[http://blackmoon.tistory.com/292 봉선홍경사사적갈비 (奉先弘慶寺事蹟碣碑); 성주사낭혜화상백월보광탑비 (聖住寺郎慧和尙白月보光塔碑)] (Includes photos of Korean monuments) {{ko icon}}</ref>
Vietnam also has a long tradition of tortoise-born stelae, where they [[:commons:Category: Vinh Lang stele|commemorate]] emperor [[Lê Lợi]] as well as the graduates of the Confucian academy at Hanoi's [[Temple of Literature, Hanoi|Temple of Literature]].
While there is no indigenous tradition of erecting stelae on tortoise-shaped pedestals in the United States, a Qing period ''bixi'' can be seen on campus of the [[Harvard University]] in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]]. [[Harvard Bixi|This bixi]] was given as a gift to Harvard in 1936 by the members of Harvard Clubs in China; an appropriate text was carved for the occasion on the tablet carried by the tortoise.
==Development as an art form== According to [[Victor Segalen]]'s assessment, the early ([[Han dynasty|Han]] and the [[Six Dynasties]]) stone tortoises were artistic images of quite real aquatic turtles.<ref name=seg68/> The creatures looked quite realistic through the [[Song dynasty]], when huge tortoise pedestals, such as the ones in [[Shou Qiu]] near [[Qufu]], or the one in [[Dai Miao]] at [[Mount Tai]] were erected.
The early-Ming specimens, while still definitely [[Green sea turtle|chelonian]], had sprouted small ears; sides of their heads and their [[carapace]]s are often decorated by a leaf-like design. They usually have prominent teeth, which real-life turtles don't.<ref name=lishuai/> By the mid-[[Qing dynasty|Qing]] (the 18th century), however, the stele-bearing tortoise becomes the characteristic [[Chinese dragon|dragon]]-headed ''bixi''. {{Clear}} <gallery mode=packed heights=170px> File:Segalen-39-Xiao-Xiu-Tortoise-and-column.jpg|[[Xiao Xiu]] mausoleum, [[Nanjing]], [[Liang dynasty]], ca. 518. Photo by [[Victor Segalen]] File:Khabarovsk stone tortoise.JPG|Tortoise from the grave of the [[Jurchen people|Jurchen]] general Asikui. Originally near [[Ussuriysk]], now in [[Khabarovsk]] Museum. [[Jin dynasty (1115-1234)]] File:Ussuriysk-Stone-Tortoise-S-3542.jpg|[[Ussuriysk]], [[Jin dynasty (1115-1234)]] File:Karakorum - Tortue Sud.jpg|[[Karakorum]] ruins, [[Yuan dynasty]] (?) File:Stone Sifangcheng.jpg|The [[Hongwu Emperor]]'s [[Ming Xiaoling Mausoleum|mausoleum]], [[Nanjing]], ca. 1400 File:Linggu-Stone-Tortoise-2901.jpg|Near [[Linggu Temple]], Nanjing, [[Ming dynasty]] File:Kangxi-Lugou-rebuilding-stele-3581.jpg|Stele in honor of the rebuilding of the [[Marco Polo Bridge]] by the [[Kangxi Emperor]], Beijing, 1668 File:Nanjing-Drum-Tower-Kangxi-stele-3042.jpg|Drum Tower, [[Nanjing]]. Commemorates visit by the Kangxi Emperor, 1684 File:MingXiaoling ZLTS01 rotated.jpg|The Kangxi Emperor's stele at [[Ming Xiaoling Mausoleum]], Nanjing 1699 File:LugouQiao-Qianlong-bridge-rebuilding-stele-3610.JPG|The [[Qianlong Emperor]]'s [[Marco Polo Bridge]] rebuilding stele, Beijing, 1785 File:Linggu-Shensong-Bixi-2911.jpg|[[Tan Yankai]] tomb, near [[Linggu Temple]], Nanjing, ca. 1930 File:Minzu-zhengqi-haoran-changcun-Bixi-3563.jpg|[[World War II]] monument in [[Wanping Castle]], [[Beijing]], 1995 File:Graves of Shimazu Tadahisa and Mori Suemitsu, Kamakura.jpg|Gravesites of [[samurai]] [[Shimazu Tadahisa]] (d. 1227) and [[Mōri Suemitsu]] (1202-1247), the founders of the [[Shimazu clan|Shimazu]] and [[Mōri clan]]s respectively, [[Kamakura period|Kamakura]], [[Japan]]. File:Bixi in Harvard University - IMG 8960.JPG|The [[Harvard Bixi]] in the [[United States]] was produced in China in the 18th century. File:Bixi Lingyin.jpg|The ''bixi'' at [[Lingyin Temple]], [[Hangzhou]], with the characters "Lingyin" (靈隱) written on the stele. </gallery>
According to some 19th-century western authors, the Chinese tradition of using a tortoise as a pedestal may have a common source with the Indian legend of the world being held up by a giant turtle.<ref>{{citation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0LoNAAAAIAAJ |title=The Chinese reader's manual: A handbook of biographical, historical, mythological and general literary reference |first= William Frederick|last= Mayers|year=1874|location=Shanghai|publisher=American Presbyterian Mission Press |page=94}}, section 299 ("Kwei, 龟"). Quote: "The conception is probably derived from the same source with that of the Hindoo legend of the tortoise supporting an elephant, on whose back the existing world reposes." Mayers is also quoted in: {{citation|first=Charles Alfred Speed|last= Williams|title=Chinese Symbolism and Art Motifs: An Alphabetical Compendium of Antique Legends and Beliefs, as Reflected in the Manners and Customs of the Chinese|publisher= Tuttle Publishing|year= 1988|ISBN= 0-8048-1586-0|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wV_3WRPC3gQC|page=405}} (reprint of the 1941 edition).</ref>
==Name== The word ''bi'' 贔 or ''bixi'' 贔屭 (also written with a variant character, 贔屓) is translated by Chinese dictionaries as "strong", "capable to support great weight". The word ''bixi'' is attested already in [[Zhang Heng]]'s (78-139) "Western Metropolis Rhapsody" (''Xi Jing Fu''), which mentions "the great strides" of the giant divine ''bixi''.<ref>"Western Metropolis Rhapsody" ([[:zh:s:西京賦|西京賦]]), Quote: "綴以二華，巨靈贔屓，高掌遠蹠，以流河曲，厥跡猶存". Quoted also in [[#yang2008|Yang Jingrong and Liu Zhixiong (2008)]]</ref> Zhang Heng's follower [[Zuo Si]] (250 - 305) in his ''[[Eastern Wu|Wu]] [[Jiankang|Capital]] [[Fu (poetry)|Rhapsody]]'' (''Wu Jing Fu'') explicitly associates the attribute ''bixi'' with the legendary giant turtle ''[[ao (turtle)|ao]]'', whose head supports a sacred mountain.<ref>"Wu Capital Rhapsody" ([[:zh:s:吳都賦|吳都賦]]), Quote: "巨鼇贔屓，首冠靈山" (Giant ''Ao'' ''bixi'' [i.e. 'mighty'], [his] head holds up a sacred mountain). Quoted also in [[#yang2008|Yang Jingrong and Liu Zhixiong (2008)]]</ref>
The term ''bixi'' became associated with the stele-carrying tortoises no later than the [[Ming dynasty]]. The terminology, however, did not immediately become stable. The earliest known Ming-era list of fantastic creatures appearing in architecture and applied art is given by [[Lu Rong]] (1436–1494) in his ''Miscellaneous records from the bean garden'' (椒园杂记, ''Shuyuan Zaji''). The ''bixi'', with the syllables swapped (屭贔, ''xibi''), appears in the first position in that list: <blockquote> The ''xibi'' looks like a tortoise. By its nature it likes to carry heavy weights. It used to be employed to support stone tablets.<ref>[[Lu Rong]]'s ''Shuyuan Zaji'' is quoted in [[#yang2008|Yang Jingrong and Liu Zhixiong (2008)]]: "屭赑其形似龟，性好负重，故用载石碑". The full text of ''Shuyuan Zaji'' can be found at a number of sites online, e.g. here: [http://xxgblog.tcip.net.cn/index.php/56/viewspace-3024.html 菽園雜記] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100306151643/http://xxgblog.tcip.net.cn/index.php/56/viewspace-3024.html |date=2010-03-06 }}</ref> </blockquote> Lu Rong claims that his list (including the total of 14 creatures) is based on the ancient books of beasts and supernatural creatures, the ''[[Shan Hai Jing]]'' and the ''Bo Wu Zhi'' (博物志); however, as the modern researchers Yang Jingrong and Liu Zhixiong note, that is not the case, and the names, much more likely, were taken by Lu Rong from the folklore of his times.<ref name=yang2008>[[#yang2008|Yang Jingrong and Liu Zhixiong (2008)]]</ref>
Soon after Lu Rong, the mighty tablet-carrying tortoise appears in various lists of the "[[Chinese dragon#Children of Dragon|Nine children of the Dragons]]", compiled by several Ming authors. However, both [[Li Dongyang]] (1441–1516) in his ''Huai Lu Tang Ji'' and Xie Zhaozhe ([[:zh:謝肇淛|謝肇淛]], 1567–1624) in his ''Wu Za Ji'' ([[:zh:五雜俎|五雜俎]], ''Five Assorted Offerings'', ca. 1592), refer to the tortoise that carries the stele by the name ''baxia'' (霸下), rather than ''bixi''; at the same time they apply the name ''bixi'' to the "literature-loving" dragons that appear on the sides of the stele: <blockquote> The ''baxia'' has an innate love for carrying weights; the creature [that] now [is] under tablets is its image. ... The ''bixi'' has an innate love for literature; the dragons [that] now [are] on the sides of tablets are its image.<ref>[[Li Dongyang]]'s ''Huai Lu Tang Ji'' (怀麓堂集) quoted in [[#yang2008|Yang Jingrong and Liu Zhixiong (2008)]]: "霸下平生好负重，今碑座兽足是其遗像。... 赑屭平生好文，今碑两旁龙是其遗像。"</ref></blockquote>
The name ''bixi'', however, is given to the table-carrying tortoise in the more popular version of the list of the "Nine Children of the Dragon". In this form of the list, given e.g. by [[Yang Shen]] (1488–1559), the ''bixi'' is given the first position: <blockquote> The ''bixi'' looks like a tortoise, and likes to carry heavy weights; [he] is the tortoise-carrier (''guifu'') now [seen] under stone tablets.<ref>[[Yang Shen]]'s ''Sheng'an Ji'' (升庵集) quoted in [[#yang2008|Yang Jingrong and Liu Zhixiong (2008)]]: "赑屭形似龟，好负重，今石碑下龟蚨是也。"</ref> </blockquote>
==Stone tortoises in art and popular lore== The great stone tortoises, whose antiquity sometimes went farther into the history than anyone could remember, often made impression on people who saw them, and excited their curiosity. It is said that an old legend of the stone tortoise made by [[Lu Ban]] that went to swim in the ocean every summer, and came back to its seaside hill in the fall, inspired [[Lu Ji (Shiheng)|Lu Ji]]'s lines: <ref name=deGroot4_341>{{citation |publisher=Brill Archive |year=1892b |first=Jan Jakob Maria |last=de Groot |title=The Religious System of China |volume=IV |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O8kUAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA341 |pages=341 }}. The legend, and the reference to [[Lu Ji (Shiheng)|Lu Ji]], comes from the book ''Shu Yi Ji'' (述异记, "Extraordinary stories"), commonly ascribed to [[Ren Fang]] (460—508). The story from the tortoise from a seaside hill (海畔石龜), as well as the one about another sea-going stone turtle from [[Linyi]] County (臨邑縣), and their translations to [[Modern Standard Mandarin]], can be found [http://www.fulan.com/167/ebook/classic/taipinggj/tpgj374.html here] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060712014209/http://www.fulan.com/167/ebook/classic/taipinggj/tpgj374.html |date=July 12, 2006 }}. </ref> <ref>Lu Ji's poem: «[http://sc.zdic.net/weijin/1223279777683632.html 石龟尚怀海。我宁忘故乡] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724140557/http://sc.zdic.net/weijin/1223279777683632.html |date=July 24, 2011 }}». Unlike modern Chinese editions, {{harvnb|de Groot|1892b|p=341}} has 亡 (to die) instead of 忘 (to forget), which changes the meaning of the second line to "I'd rather die in my home village."</ref> {{quote| The stone tortoise cherishes in its heart the love of the sea.<br> How can I forget my home village? }}
The opening chapter of the 14th-century novel ''[[Water Margin]]'' involves Marshal Hong releasing 108 spirits imprisoned under an ancient stele-bearing tortoise. <ref>{{citation|first=Jing |last=Wang|publisher=Duke University Press |year=1992|isbn=0-8223-1195-X |title=The story of stone: intertextuality, ancient Chinese stone lore, and the stone symbolism in Dream of the red chamber, Water margin, and The journey to the west |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=49brOdOKlD0C | pages=252–254 }}, which includes the English translation of the relevant excerpt from the novel. The original text of the chapter can be seen e.g. at [[:zh:s:水滸傳/第001回|水滸傳/第001回]], starting from "只中央一個石碑，約高五六尺，下面石龜趺坐 ..."</ref>
A ''bixi'' plays a key role in a ghost story, "The Spirit of the Stone Tortoise" (贔屭精, ''Bixi jing''), from [[Yuan Mei]]'s (1716–1797) collection ''[[Zi Bu Yu|What the Master does not Speak of]]''.<ref>Jennifer Thome, [https://scholar.google.com/ STRANGE OVERTONES: THE EXPRESSIONS OF RESENTMENT AND COMPASSION IN YUAN MEI’S WHAT THE MASTER DOES NOT SPEAK OF] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090903014320/https://scholar.google.com/ |date=September 3, 2009 }}. M.A. thesis, Arizona State University, 2008.</ref>
The French poet and researcher [[Victor Segalen]] (1878–1919), who published both a scholarly book about China's stelae<ref>{{harvnb|Segalen|2005}}</ref> and a book of poetry-in-prose about them,<ref>{{harvnb|Segalen|2007}}</ref> was also impressed by the "truly emblematic" stone tortoises, their "firm gestures and [[elegy|elegiac]] posture".<ref name=segalen>{{harvnb|Segalen|2007|pp=52–53}}</ref>
Today, the image of the ''bixi'' continues to inspire modern Chinese artists.<ref>Qiu Zhijie, [https://archive.is/20130131212441/http://www.qiuzhijie.com/image/Performance/nanjing/shiban/%E5%A4%B1%E8%B4%A5%E4%B9%8B%E5%9F%8E.JPG "City of failure"] - the print is based on the Sifangcheng pavilion in the [[Ming Xiaoling Mausoleum]].</ref>
==Preservation concerns== As with other stone (particularly, marble and limestone) statuary, ''bixi'' turtles and their stelae are vulnerable to [[acid rain]] (or, in winter, acid snow). On the Harvard University campus, the curators of [[Harvard Bixi|its turtle]] protect it against the "acid snow" by wrapping it with a waterproof cover for the winter.<ref>"[http://harvardmagazine.com/2000/03/art-under-wraps.html Art Under Wraps]" , Harvard Magazine, March–April 2000</ref>
A more ''bixi''-specific concern is the wear to the creatures' noses from the people who touch them for good luck. At Hanoi's [[Temple of Literature, Hanoi|Temple of Literature]], highly popular with visitors, this has become a sufficient concern to the site's managers as to make them develop plans for introducing creative landscaping and structural obstacles to keep visitors from touching the temple's 82 stone turtles.<ref name=lishuai>The custom of rubbing ''bixi'' for good luck (or, rather, protection from bag luck) is attested elsewhere e.g. in: 李帅 (Li Shuai), 毛朝青 (Mao Chaoqing), [http://news.ifeng.com/a/20150114/42931143_0.shtml 赑屃不是龟. 专职驮石碑] (Bixi is not a turtle. Its special duty is to hold a stone table), 海峡都市报, 2015-01-14</ref><ref>{{citation|url=http://www.ttrweekly.com/site/2012/09/hanois-stone-turtles-at-risk/ |title=Hanoi’s stone turtles at risk |date=September 27, 2012|author= Wanwisa Ngamsangchaikit }}</ref>

==References== *{{citation|first= Victor|last= Segalen|url=http://classiques.uqac.ca/classiques/segalen_victor/C18_chine_grande_statuaire/grande_statuaire.html |title="Chine. La grande statuaire", and "Les origines de la statuaire en Chine"|series=Collections Bouquins|publisher=Editions Robert Laffont |location= Paris|year=1995}} (Posthumous publication, based on research done in 1909-1917) *{{citation |first=Victor |last=Segalen |editor-first=Timothy James |editor-last=Billings|editor2-first= Christopher |editor2-last=Bush |publisher=Wesleyan University Press |year=2007|isbn=0-8195-6832-5 |title=Stèles, Volume 1|series=Wesleyan Poetry Series |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=fMRSgMh5JE0C}} Includes Segalen's original text and the English translation Timothy James Billings and Christopher Bush. The original was published in 1912; its text can be also found at http://www.steles.net/ * {{citation|publisher=中国书店|year=2008|isbn=7-80663-551-3|url=http://vip.book.sina.com.cn/book/catalog.php?book=69989 |author1=杨静荣 (Yang Jingrong)|author2= 刘志雄 (Liu Zhixiong)|ref=yang2008 |title=龙之源 (The Origin of the Dragon) |at=Chapter 9, 龙的繁衍与附会——龙生九子 (Dragon's derived and associated creatures: The nine children of the dragon)}} ([http://vip.book.sina.com.cn/book/chapter_69989_55313.html Section 1], [http://vip.book.sina.com.cn/book/chapter_69989_55314.html Section 2], [http://vip.book.sina.com.cn/book/chapter_69989_55315.html Section 3]).
==External links== * [http://www.chinese-handicraft.com/ancient-relics/Stele_on_the_Back_of_Stone_Tortoise_60.html Stele on the Back of Stone Tortoise] (an overview of the ''Bixi'' tradition)
[[Category:Chinese iconography]] [[Category:Chinese architectural history]] [[Category:Chinese sculpture]] [[Category:Chinese legendary creatures]] [[Category:Chinese mythology]] [[Category:Fictional turtles]] [[Category:Animals in art]]

{{unreferenced|date=August 2009}} <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:StarWarsBookAndRecord.JPG|thumb|150px|A book-and-record set for ''[[Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope]]'' {{ffdc|1=StarWarsBookAndRecord.JPG|log=2014 December 22}}]] --> '''Book-and-record sets''' are a form of entertainment for children, consisting of a picture storybook (often in [[comic book]] format, with drawings or photos) and an accompanying recording (originally in the form of a [[vinyl record]]; later in [[cassette tape]] and [[compact disc]] formats) to be played while following along with the book. The record and book complement one another, with the record usually a [[radio theater]]-style version of the story or a [[soundtrack]] recording, and the book providing visuals and text to the story. Often a tone or other kind of cue in the recording will prompt the reader to turn pages.
Book-and-record sets are popular as teaching tools and aids to reading, and as a simple form of [[multimedia]] entertainment. [[Cartoon characters]] are common subjects (or stars) of the stories, as are comic book [[superhero|superheroes]] and other [[Franchise (media)|media franchises]], characters and personalities. Occasionally popular children's or family movies are adapted for book and record; the stories may either be re-presented by a new cast of performers, members of the movie cast, or the audio taken directly from the movie, with narration added.
[[Disneyland Records]] and related companies produced several such works, as did [[Peter Pan Records]] (and its offshoot [[Power Records (Peter Pan records)|Power Records]]) and others, from the dawn of [[long-playing records]] and the [[45rpm single]] until the digital age. In the late 1940s and early 1950s, [[Capitol Records]] produced many book-and-record sets for children, ranging from everything from [[Bozo the Clown]] to the classical music fantasy ''[[Sparky's Magic Piano]]''. A "picture storybook" of the 1982 movie ''[[E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial]]'' narrated by [[Michael Jackson]] became a highly prized [[collectible]], after it went out of print. Newer sets may still be found among recordings for children.
{{Portal |Children's literature}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Book-And-Record Set}} [[Category:Books by type]] [[Category:Children's literature]] [[Category:Educational materials]] [[Category:Album types]] [[Category:Storytelling]]

{{distinguish|text=the [[Castellani Art Museum]] at Niagara University, New York}}
'''Castellani House''' is a large nineteenth-century building, which is situated on the corner of Vlissengen Road and Homestretch Avenue in [[Georgetown, Guyana|Georgetown]], [[Guyana]]. It was designed and constructed by the Maltese architect, [[Cesar Castellani]], between 1879 and 1882. Originally serving as a residence for colonial government officials, Castellani House has been the home of '''Guyana's National Art Gallery''' since 1993.<ref name=Kandasammy>{{cite news|last=Kandasammy|first=Lloyd F.|title=Around the Museums of Guyana|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2492&dat=20080424&id=TkZaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=oSYMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2195,8128801|accessdate=20 August 2012|newspaper=Stabroek News|date=24 April 2008|pages=20-22}}</ref><ref name=Smock>{{cite book|last=Smock|first=Kirk|title=Guyana: The Bradt Travel Guide|year=2011|publisher=Bradt Travel Guides|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=SunsxFAaCWgC&pg=PA121&lpg=PA121&dq=castellani+house+vlissengen+rd+homestretch+av&source=bl&ots=2u1CRkRuu1&sig=ay5DZB96Po82ItdRC-ehpi0rUck&hl=en&sa=X&ei=9ucyUNLsBajT0QWSuoHgBQ&ved=0CDYQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=castellani%20house%20vlissengen%20rd%20homestretch%20av&f=false|edition=2nd|chapter=Chapter 4: Georgetown}}</ref><ref name=Baksh>{{cite news|last=Baksh|first=Shaleeza|title=National Art Gallery promises to maintain international standards|url=http://www.landofsixpeoples.com/news/nc106175.htm|accessdate=20 August 2012|newspaper=Guyana Chronicle|date=17 June 2001}}</ref><ref name=Lynch>{{cite journal|last=Lynch|first=Ruth Anne|title=Guyana's Got it Going On|journal=Caribbean Beat|date=January–February 2009|volume=107|url=http://caribbean-beat.com/issue-107/guyana%E2%80%99s-got-it-going|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130421064156/http://www.caribbean-beat.com/issue-107/guyana%E2%80%99s-got-it-going|archivedate=2013-04-21|df=}}</ref><ref name=Creighton>{{cite news|last=Creighton|first=Al|title=An Outstanding Year for Castellani House|url=http://www.landofsixpeoples.com/news604/ns6123111.html|accessdate=18 August 2012|newspaper=Stabroek News|date=31 December 2006}}</ref>
==History==
Castellani House was designed and built in by [[Cesar Castellani]], who was one of the most prominent and prolific architects of the colonial era in [[British Guiana]]. It was originally designed as a residence for the government [[botanist]], [[George Samuel Jenman]]. Dissatisfied with the original design of the house, Jenman refused to move into the residence until the changes he demanded had been implemented. These changes were completed in 1882, and Jenman moved into the house in that year. After Jenman died, Castellani House was used as the official residence for Directors of Agriculture.<ref name=Kandasammy /><ref name=Baksh />
In 1942, the house was extended with the addition of a third storey to the original two. In 1965, further changes were made to the structure of the house by the Guyanese architect, Hugh McGregor Reid.<ref name=Kandasammy />
From 1965 to 1985, Castellani House was the Official Residence for Prime Minister [[Forbes Burnham]] and First Lady, Viola Burnham. During this time it was known simply as "the Residence".<ref name=Kandasammy /><ref name=NTG>{{cite web|last=National Trust of Guyana|title=Historic Bourda|url=http://www.nationaltrust.gov.gy/new/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=83&Itemid=163|work=National Trust of Guyana Official Website|accessdate=20 August 2012}}</ref>
After a major refurbishment, Castellani House was re-opened as the home of the National Art Gallery in 1993.<ref name=Kandasammy/><ref name=Creighton /><ref name=NTG /> The Gallery's first curator was Everley Austin (1994-1996). Austin was followed by Elfrieda Bissember (1996-present).<ref name=Creighton />
==Art collection==
Castellani House holds over 700 works of art. The collection includes work by [[Frank Bowling]], [[Edward Rupert Burrowes|E. R. Burrowes]], [[Stanley Greaves]], [[Bernadette Persaud]], [[George Simon (artist and archaeologist)|George Simon]], [[Denis Williams]] and [[Aubrey Williams]].<ref name=Kandasammy /><ref name=Baksh /><ref name=Lynch /><ref name=Creighton />
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{coord|6.80604|-58.14992|display=title}}
