Conspiracy Theory |date=16 April 2018 |publisher=[[Newsweek]]}} and supported{{cite web|url=https://www.splcenter.org/hatewatch/2017/12/21/hatewatch-headlines-12212017 |title=How badly is the Bundy case screwed up? Media gear up for voting-rights assault; Faith Goldy recites, embraces the '14 Words'; and more |date=21 December 2017 |publisher=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]]}} the Fourteen Words,{{cite news |author=Tom Yun |url=https://thevarsity.ca/2018/03/26/open-letter-petitions-u-of-t-to-rescind-faith-goldys-student-leadership-award/ |title=Open letter petitions U of T to rescind Faith Goldy's student leadership award |date=26 March 2018|newspaper=[[The Varsity (newspaper)|The Varsity]]}}{{cite web |author=Nick Taylor |url=http://www.trentarthur.ca/cant-welcome-faith-goldy/ |title=Why We Can't Welcome Faith Goldy |date=27 March 2018 |newspaper=[[Arthur (newspaper)|Arthur]]}} saying "I don't see that as controversial... We want to survive."{{cite news |author=Mari Uyehara |url=https://www.gq.com/story/how-free-speech-warriors-mainstreamed-white-supremacists |title=How Free Speech Warriors Mainstreamed White Supremacists |date=8 May 2018|publisher=[[GQ]]}} After being banned by [[Patreon]] for her advocacy of the slogan, Goldy defended her views, and gathered petition signatures in public on a document which replaced "white children" with "[[Aboriginal child protection|aboriginal children]]", to supposedly prove the slogan was not hate speech.{{cite web |author=Jared Holt |url=http://www.rightwingwatch.org/post/faith-goldy-defends-her-recital-of-14-words/ |title=Faith Goldy Defends Her Recital Of '14 Words' |date=29 May 2018 |publisher=[[Right Wing Watch]]}} *[[Marian Kotleba]], a Slovak politician and leader of the far-right [[Kotleba – People's Party Our Slovakia]] political party, has been accused of demonstrating support for the slogan,{{cite news |url=https://spectator.sme.sk/c/20881113/kotleba-of-lsns-charged-with-extremism.html |title=Kotleba of ĽSNS charged with extremism |date=30 July 2018 |newspaper=[[The Slovak Spectator]]}} with supposed reference to the Fourteen Words by making a €1,488 donation to charity,{{cite news |author=Blaise Gauquelin |url=https://www.lemonde.fr/international/article/2017/08/02/le-fuhrer-slovaque-de-banska-bystrica-inquiete-par-la-justice_5167684_3210.html |title=Le " Führer " slovaque de Banska Bystrica inquiété par la justice |language=FR |trans-title=Slovak "Führer" from Banska Bystrica worried about justice |date=2 August 2017 |newspaper=[[Le Monde]]}}{{cite news |url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/slovak-far-right-leader-charged-with-promoting-extremism/ |title=Slovak far-right leader charged with promoting extremism |date=28 July 2018 |publisher=[[The Times of Israel]] |agency=Agence France-Presse}} which he is facing criminal charges for in Slovakia.{{cite news |author=Tatiana Jancarikova |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-slovakia-extremism/police-charge-leader-of-slovak-far-right-party-with-extremism-idUSKBN1AD223 |title=Police charge leader of Slovak far-right party with extremism |date=28 July 2017 |publisher=Reuters}} *[[Saga (singer)|Saga]], a Swedish white nationalist singer-songwriter, long-time supporter of the 14 Words slogan and personal friend of Lane; turned his poetry into music format and released the CD ''On My Own'' which includes the song "Goodbye [[David Lane (white nationalist)|David Lane]]", a variant of "[[Candle in the Wind]]" as part of his euology.{{cite web|url=http://www.thisissaga.com/mymusic-onmyown-lyrics.html|title=thisissaga.com|publisher=Thisisaga|accessdate=18 January 2015}}{{dead link|date=October 2018}}{{cite web |author=Edmund Standing |url=https://lemosandcrane.co.uk/resources/bnponline.pdf |title=BNP Media |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2018-09-19}} *[[Varg Vikernes]], a Norwegian [[National Socialist Black Metal]] musician and proponent of the [[white genocide conspiracy theory]] who regularly uses "14" and "88" numerology in the videos of his Thulean Perspective channel on Youtube. ==2018 United States DHS press release== In 2018, although dismissed by the US government as a coincidence,{{cite news |author=Blake Montgomery |url=https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/blakemontgomery/homeland-security-statement-theory |title=Homeland Security Officials Say Claims That Statement Mimics A White Supremacist Slogan Are Merely Conspiracy Theories |quote=The February press release has a 14-word title, "We Must Secure The Border And Build The Wall To Make America Safe Again", which resembles the grammatical structure of a common white supremacist slogan |date=29 June 2018 |publisher=[[BuzzFeed]]}} the Trump administration's [[United States Department of Homeland Security]] were accused of referencing both "88" in a document,{{cite news |author=Aviya Kushner |url=https://forward.com/culture/404371/are-14-and-88-nazi-dog-whistles-in-this-homeland-security-document-or-just/ |title=Are '14' And '88' Nazi Dog Whistles In Border Security Document — Or Just Numbers? |date=28 June 2018 |newspaper=[[The Forward]]}} and the Fourteen Words by creating a similar fourteen-worded title,{{cite news |author= Chauncey DeVega |url=https://www.salon.com/2018/07/06/did-trump-administration-send-a-coded-signal-to-neo-nazis-maybe-not-but-is-that-reassuring/ |title=Did Trump administration send a coded signal to neo-Nazis? Maybe not — but is that reassuring? |date=6 July 2018 |publisher=[[Salon (website)|Salon]]}} starting with the same first three words ("We must secure"), in relation to illegal immigration and border control:
We Must Secure The Border And Build The Wall To Make America Safe Again.{{cite press release |url=https://www.dhs.gov/news/2018/02/15/we-must-secure-border-and-build-wall-make-america-safe-again |title=We Must Secure The Border And Build The Wall To Make America Safe Again |quote=On average, out of 88 claims that pass the credible fear screening, fewer than 13 will ultimately result in a grant of asylum |date=15 February 2018 |publisher=[[United States Department of Homeland Security]]}}
A press release issued in February 2018 on the [[United States Department of Homeland Security|US Department of Homeland Security]] (DHS) website included a title with fourteen words similarly structured to the white supremacist phrase ("We Must Secure The Border And Build The Wall To Make America Safe Again"). The release also included a reference to the number '88' in the text: "On average, out of 88 claims that pass the credible fear screening, fewer than 13 will ultimately result in a grant of asylum." The similarity was widely shared on social media.{{cite news |last1=Kalmbacher |first1=Colin |title=Twitter Explodes After Homeland Security Headline Appears to Mimic '14-Words' Neo-Nazi Slogan |url=https://lawandcrime.com/high-profile/twitter-explodes-after-homeland-security-headline-appears-to-mimic-14-words-neo-nazi-slogan/ |work=lawandcrime.com |date=28 June 2018 |accessdate=29 June 2018}} DHS dismissed the similarity as a conspiracy theory, and journalist [[Chris Hayes]] attributed the unusual use of 88 as a statistical artifact of how DHS processes asylum seekers. == References related to terrorism and violence == [[File:CurtisAllgier.jpg|thumb|[[White power skinhead|Skinhead]] murderer [[Curtis Allgier]] has tattoos of "14" and "88"]] The slogans and numerology of "14" and "88" have been used by many white supremacists, both before and after committing violence (such as in manifestos), as well as symbolically within criminal acts. These include Order-member [[David Lane (white supremacist)|David Lane]], assassination attempters Paul Schlesselman and Daniel Cowart, and murderers [[Dylann Roof]]{{cite news|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/dylann-roof-s-videotaped-confessions-stuns-courtroom-n694036|title=Dylann Roof's Videotaped Confession Stuns Courtroom |last=Siemaszko|first=Corky|date=December 9, 2016|work=[[NBCNews.com]]|accessdate=8 January 2017}} and [[Curtis Allgier]].{{cite news|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/680194690/Tattoos-tell-a-tale-of-intimidation.html|title=Tattoos tell a tale of intimidation |last=Reavy |first=Pat |date=June 28, 2007|work=[[Deseret News]]|accessdate=8 January 2017}} Allgier has "14" and "88" tattooed on his forehead above and to the sides of the words "skin" and "head" above his eyes in his mugshot. === Murder of Alan Berg === {{Main article|Alan Berg}} The assassination of [[Jewish]] talk show host [[Alan Berg]] in June 1984, is considered as [[The Order (white supremacist group)|The Order]]'s most infamous act of terrorism. Order member Bruce Pierce served as the gunman in the murder and Lane the getaway driver.{{cite web|url=https://www.splcenter.org/hatewatch/2010/08/18/death-assassin-order's-bruce-pierce-dies-prison|title=Hatewatch|publisher=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]]}}{{cite web|url=https://www.splcenter.org/fighting-hate/intelligence-report/2007/terrorist-14-words-author-dies-prison |title=Terrorist, '14 Words' Author, Dies in Prison |date=1 October 2017 |publisher=[[Southern Poverty Law Center]]}} During Lane's imprisonment on separate convictions (some relating to violating Alan Berg's civil rights) he created the Fourteen Words slogan. The number 14 continues to symbolize allegiance to the [[Aryan Nations]]' vision of a [[Northwest Territorial Imperative|white homeland]].{{cite web |author=Meagan Day |date=4 November 2016 |url=https://timeline.com/white-supremacist-rural-paradise-fb62b74b29e0 |title=Welcome to Hayden Lake, where white supremacists tried to build their homeland |publisher=Timeline}} === Barack Obama assassination plot === {{Main article|Barack Obama assassination plot in Tennessee}} "14/88" numerology was symbolically included in the [[Barack Obama]] assassination plot in October 2008. Both Neo-Nazis, Schlesselman and Cowart were introduced to each other online by a mutual friend who shared their white supremacist beliefs.{{cite news|url=http://archive.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2008/10/28/skinhead_plot_news_sweeps_suspects_tenn_hometown/|title=Authorities say skinhead plot wasn't fully formed|last1=Baird|first1=Woody|date=2008-10-30|newspaper=[[Associated Press]] |last2=DeMillo |first2=Andrew |accessdate=2017-11-29}} Within a month of meeting, they had planned to kill the Democratic Party nominee by driving at their target and shooting from their vehicle. This was to be followed by a killing spree in which the men planned to kill 88 [[African American]]s, 14 of whom were to be beheaded. They were targeting mostly children at an unidentified, predominantly [[Black people|black]] school.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/28/us/politics/28plot.html?scp=1&sq=Daniel%20Cowart&st=cse|title=Arrests in plan to kill Obama and black schoolchildren|last=Lichtblau|first=Eric|date=2008-10-27|newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |author-link=Eric Lichtblau |accessdate=2008-10-28}} Shortly after their arrest, their vehicle was discovered to have "14" and "88" written onto it. === Wisconsin Sikh temple shooting === {{Main article|Wisconsin Sikh temple shooting}} Mass-shooter [[Wade Michael Page]], who killed six and wounded four members of the [[Sikhism in the United States|Sikh community]] in August 2012, had been a supporter of the Fourteen Words, and was found with "14" onto a [[Celtic Cross]] tattooed on his arm,{{cite news |author=Adam Weinstein |url=https://www.motherjones.com/crime-justice/2012/08/wade-michael-page-tattoos-sikh-temple-shooting/ |title=The Sikh Temple Shooter's Racist Tattoos, Deciphered |date=6 August 2012 |publisher=[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]}} after committing suicide at the scene of the crime.{{cite news |author=Matthew Goodwin |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/aug/08/wade-michael-page-violent-far-right |title=Wade Michael Page and the rise of violent far-right extremism |date=8 August 2012 |newspaper=[[The Guardian]]}}{{cite news |author=Abby Rogers |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/heres-what-made-wade-michael-page-racist-2012-8 |title=Wade Michael Page Became A Radical Racist In The US Army |date=10 August 2012 |publisher=[[Business Insider]]}} About a year before the shooting, Page wrote on the Internet regarding the slogan, "Passive submission is indirect support to the oppressors. Stand up for yourself and live the 14 words."{{cite news |author=Russell Goldman |url=https://abcnews.go.com/Blotter/wisconsin-gunman-wade-michael-pages-tattoos-racist-beliefs/story?id=16949676 |title=Cracking Wisconsin Gunman's Secret Racist Tattoo Code |date=7 August 2012 |publisher=[[ABC News]]}} === Charleston church shooting === {{Main article|Charleston church massacre}} After the Charleston mass-murder shooting in June 2015, [[Dylann Roof]]'s ideology and apparent manifesto emerged in the media with multiple references to "1488",{{cite news |author=Clara Jeffery |author2=James West |url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2015/06/references-dylann-roof-manifesto-explained-1488/ |title=The Deeply Racist References in Dylann Roof's Apparent Manifesto, Decoded. |date=20 June 2015 |publisher=[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]}} these included several photos of Roof pictured alongside the numbers.{{cite news |author=Rob Crilly |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/11689037/Charleston-church-massacre-Things-we-learned-from-shooter-Dylann-Roofs-racist-manifesto.html |title=Charleston church massacre: Things we learned from shooter Dylann Roof's racist manifesto |date=21 June 2015 |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]}} He symbolically brought 88 bullets to the [[Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church]] to carry out the shooting, in which nine [[African Americans]] were killed.{{cite news |author=AJ Willingham |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2017/02/21/us/hate-symbols-changing-trnd/index.html |title=These are the new symbols of hate |date=22 February 2017 |publisher=CNN}}{{cite news |author=Tonya Maxwell |author2=Tim Smith |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2017/01/10/dylann-roof-sentencing/96412218/ |title=Federal jury sentences Dylann Roof to death |date=11 January 2017 |newspaper=[[USA Today]]}} === Pittsburgh synagogue shooting === {{Main article|Pittsburgh synagogue shooting}} Robert Bowers, the gunman suspected of killing 11 people and wounding 6 at the Tree of Life Synagogue in [[Pittsburgh]], Pennsylvania, included the numeric code "1488" in the header image of his [[Gab (social network)|Gab]] social media account.{{cite news|url=https://heavy.com/news/2018/10/robert-bowers-social-media-rob-gab|title=Robert Bowers: See Squirrel Hill Suspect's Social Media|date=October 27, 2018|publisher=Heavy.com}}https://www.thedailybeast.com/robert-bowers-is-neo-nazi-who-posted-about-killing-jews-on-gab Bowers also expressed [[Christian Identity]] rhetoric declaring "the lord jesus christ is come in the flesh" while espousing anti-Semitic views that "jews are children of satan".{{cite news |author1=Katie Zezima |author2=Wesley Lowery |date=October 27, 2018 |title=Suspected synagogue shooter appears to have railed against Jews, refugees online |newspaper=The Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/amphtml/national/suspected-synagogue-shooter-appears-to-have-railed-against-jews-refugees-online/2018/10/27/e99dd282-da18-11e8-a10f-b51546b10756_story.html}} ==See also== * [[Northwest Territorial Imperative]] * [[White genocide conspiracy theory]] * [[White separatism]] == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Neo-fascism]] [[Category:Neo-Nazism]] [[Category:Slogans]] [[Category:White nationalist symbols]]

revision.comment: /* Goudy Award honorees, dates of award, birthdates, professions */
revision.text:
The '''Frederic W. Goudy Award''' & Lecture were established in 1969 by funds donated to [[Rochester Institute of Technology]] (RIT) by the [[Mary Flagler Cary]] Charitable Trust in memory of Mrs. Cary's late husband, [[Melbert Cary|Melbert B. Cary, Jr.]], a [[typographer]], type importer, fine printer, book collector, and president of [[AIGA]] (American Institute of Graphic Arts).[http://library.rit.edu/cary/exhibitions/rit-frederic-w-goudy-award The RIT Frederic W. Goudy Award: 27 Years of Excellence in Typography] The award was named after illustrious American type designer [[Frederic W. Goudy]], a friend and business associate of Mr. Cary. In the Preface to the book ''Twenty Years of the Frederic W. Goudy Award'' [http://ritpress.rit.edu/publications/books/twenty-years-frederic-w-goudy-award.html Twenty Years of the Frederic W. Goudy Award][http://albert.rit.edu/record=b1237423 Twenty Years of the Frederic W. Goudy Award] (Press of the Good Mountain, RIT 1988), Alexander Lawson, RIT Cary Professor emeritus and 1979 recipient of the Goudy Award, wrote:
"The Cary Trustees also funded an annual Frederic W. Goudy Award to be given to an outstanding practitioner in the field of typography. The person would deliver a Goudy Lecture and meet with students in class and in groups, thus providing an opportunity for informal contact with a distinguished graphic arts figure."
In the "Foreword" to the same book, Mark Guldin, then Cary Professor, former chair of the School of Printing and former Dean of the RIT College of Imaging Arts and Sciences, wrote:
"Down through the years, we have always tried to choose those designers and typophiles for the Award who have that thread of attachment to Frederic W. Goudy, those who have worked with the design of [[typeface]]s and those who have produced designs cradled in the traditional values of [[Johannes Gutenberg|Gutenberg]], [[Nicolas Jenson|Jenson]], [[Aldus Manutius|Aldus]], [[John Baskerville|Baskerville]], and [[Giambattista Bodoni|Bodoni]]. Goudy cherished those traditional values."
The Goudy Award and Lecture was given annually from 1969 to 1995. It was discontinued in 1996 when the institute diverted the funding to other purposes. It was revived in 2012, discontinued again, and revived again in 2015. Printing and typography RIT alumni and friends of the Cary Collection hope it shall continue annually. ==Recipients of the Goudy Award== In the first years of the Goudy Award, some of the honorees had known Fred Goudy personally, thereby establishing a direct link with the eponymous past. Although that generation of typographers has passed on, along with much of the analog typographic technology and industry that Goudy and Cary were familiar with, many of Goudy's typefaces, long admired and cherished by typographic aficionados, live on and remain popular in digital formats, while new typeface designs by several Goudy Award honorees have become widely popular in digital form. Goudy Award honorees have generally been outstanding practitioners in the field of typography, including some or all of the following professions: * Professional typographer and/or typographic designer * Typeface designer or lettering artist * Creator of designs and printing in the tradition Goudy cherished * Personal and/or cultural connection to Goudy * Educator, historian, scholar, and/or author in the fields of typography, printing, or lettering The work of the Goudy Award honorees reveals another, implicit criterion: they elevated the artistic, scholarly, and ethical level of typography, whether through type design, like [[Hermann Zapf]], [[Gudrun Zapf-von Hesse|Gudrun Zapf-Von Hesse]], [[Adrian Frutiger]], [[Matthew Carter]], and [[Kris Holmes]]; through the art of fine printing, like [[Will Carter (printer)|Will Carter]], Henry Morris, and [[Giovanni Mardersteig]]; through artistic typography and printing in commercial publishing and graphic design, like Roderick Stinehour, [[Bradbury Thompson]], and [[Robert Bringhurst]]; through engagement in the social issues and responsibilities of typography, like [[Edna Beilenson]] and Robert (Doc) Leslie, and through typographic education and scholarship, like Alexander Lawson, [[John Dreyfus]], [[Warren Chappell]], and [[Charles Bigelow (type designer)|Charles Bigelow]]. Goudy Award honorees have been among the most honored and admired figures in the typographic arts. Two have received [[MacArthur Prize Fellowship|MacArthur Prize Fellowships]] (Bigelow, Carter). Four have received the [[AIGA medal|AIGA Medal]] (Mardersteig, Leslie, Thompson, Carter). Four have received the Mainz Gutenberg Award (Mardersteig, Zapf, Frutiger, Dreyfus). Nine have received the Type Directors Club Medal (Zapf, Middleton, Leslie, Thompson, Frutiger, Craw, Benguiat, Carter, Lange). Others have received numerous honors and awards in England, Europe, and America. == Goudy Award honorees, dates of award, birthdates, professions == # 1969 [[Hermann Zapf]] (b. 1918) (type design, calligraphy, typography, lettering art) [http://library.rit.edu/cary/goudyzapf Hermann Zapf, Goudy Award Winner 1] # 1970 [[Warren Chappell]] (b. 1904) (book design, type design, illustration) [http://library.rit.edu/cary/exhibitions/rit-frederic-w-goudy-award Warren Chappell, Goudy Award Winner 2] # 1971 [[R. Hunter Middleton]] (b. 1898) (type design, book design) [http://library.rit.edu/cary/goudymiddleton R. Hunter Middleton, Goudy Award Winner 3] # 1972 Dr. [[Giovanni Mardersteig]] (b. 1892) (fine printing, type design) [http://library.rit.edu/cary/goudymardersteig Giovanni Mardersteig, Goudy Award Winner 4] # 1973 Dr. [[Robert L. Leslie]] (b. 1885) (typography) [http://library.rit.edu/cary/goudyleslie Robert Lincoln Leslie, Goudy Award Winner 5] # 1974 [[P. J. Conkwright]] (b. 1905) (typography, book design) [http://library.rit.edu/cary/goudyconkwright P. J. Conkwright, Goudy Award Winner 6] # 1975 [[Will Carter (printer)|Will Carter]] (b. 1912) (fine printing, type design) [http://library.rit.edu/cary/goudywillcarter Will Carter, Goudy Award Winner 7] # 1976 Rev. [[Edward Catich]] (b. 1906) (calligraphy, lettering art, scholarship) [http://library.rit.edu/cary/goudycatich Edward M. Catich, Goudy Award Winner 8] # 1977 Laurance Siegfried (b. 1892) (typography) [http://library.rit.edu/cary/goudysiegfried Laurance Siegfried, Goudy Award Winner 9] # 1978 Howard King (b. ?) (typography) [http://library.rit.edu/cary/goudyking Howard N. King, Goudy Award Winner 10] # 1979 Alexander Lawson (b. 1913) (typography, education, scholarship) [http://library.rit.edu/cary/goudylawson Alexander S. Lawson, Goudy Award Winner 11] # 1980 [[Edna Beilenson]] (b. 1909) (publishing) [http://library.rit.edu/cary/goudybeilenson Edna Beilenson, Goudy Award Winner 12] # 1981 Freeman Craw (b. 1918) (graphic design, type design) [http://library.rit.edu/cary/goudycraw Freeman Craw, Goudy Award Winner 13] # 1982 [[Berthold Wolpe]] (b. 1905) (type design, lettering art) [http://library.rit.edu/cary/goudywolpe Berthold Wolpe, Goudy Award Winner 14] # 1983 [[Bradbury Thompson]] (b. 1911) (graphic design, typography) [http://library.rit.edu/cary/goudythompson Bradbury Thompson, Goudy Award Winner 15] # 1984 John Dreyfus (b. 1918) (typography, book design, scholarship) [http://library.rit.edu/cary/goudydreyfus John Dreyfus, Goudy Award Winner 16] # 1985 Roderick Stinehour (b. 1925) (fine printing, typography) [http://library.rit.edu/cary/goudystinehour Roderick Stinehour, Goudy Award Winner 17] # 1986 [[Matthew Carter]] (b. 1937) (type design) [http://library.rit.edu/cary/goudymtcarter Matthew Carter, Goudy Award Winner 18] # 1987 [[Charles Bigelow (type designer)|Charles Bigelow]] (b. 1945) (typography, type design, education, scholarship) [http://library.rit.edu/cary/goudybigelow Charles Bigelow, Goudy Award Winner 19] # 1988 [[Adrian Frutiger]] (b. 1928) (type design, lettering art) [http://library.rit.edu/cary/goudyfrutiger Adrian Frutiger, Goudy Award Winner 20] # 1989 Günter Gerhard Lange (b. 1921) (type design, lettering art) [http://library.rit.edu/cary/goudylange G. G. Lange, Goudy Award Winner 21] # 1990 [[Ed Benguiat]] (b. 1927) (type design, lettering art) [http://library.rit.edu/cary/goudybenguiat Ed Benguiat, Goudy Award Winner 22] # 1991 [[Gudrun Zapf von Hesse]] (b. 1918) (type design, calligraphy, book binding) [http://library.rit.edu/cary/goudygzapf Gudrun Zapf von Hesse, Goudy Award Winner 23] # 1992 Henry Morris (b. 1925) (typography, fine printing) [http://library.rit.edu/cary/goudymorris Henry Morris, Goudy Award Winner 24] # 1993 [[Walter Tracy]] (b. 1914) (type design, typography) [http://library.rit.edu/cary/goudytracy Walter Tracy, Goudy Award Winner 25] # 1995 Robert Norton (b. 1929) (typography, type design) [http://library.rit.edu/cary/goudynorton Robert Norton, Goudy Award Winner 26] # 2012 [[Kris Holmes]] (b. 1950) (type design, calligraphy, lettering art, animation) [http://library.rit.edu/cary/goudyholmes Kris Holmes, Goudy Award Winner 27] # 2015 Jerry Kelly (b. 1955) (calligraphy, book design, scholarship, type design)[http://library.rit.edu/cary/news/jerry-kelly-named-28th-goudy-awardee Jerry Kelly Goudy Award Winner 28] # 2016 [[Robert Bringhurst]] (b. 1946) (typography, book design, scholarship, poetry, First Nation literature) [https://www.rit.edu/news/story.php?id=57314 Robert Bringhurst, Goudy Award Winner 29] # 2017 [[Claire Van Vliet]] (b. 1933) (typography, fine arts, illustration) {{Cite web|url=https://www.rit.edu/news/story.php?id=64598|title=Claire Van Vliet, Goudy Award Winner 30|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} [[Category:Typography]] [[Category:Design awards]] [[Category:Rochester Institute of Technology]]

revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:Gastronomicon.jpg|thumb|Gastronomicon--cover by Les Petersen]] <!-- FAIR USE of Gastro.JPG: see image description page at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Gastro.JPG for rationale -->
'''''Gastronomicon''''' is a short story and recipe collection published by the Canberra Speculative Fiction Guild. Printed in 2005 and edited by [[Stuart Barrow]], it contains stories and recipes from several Australian [[speculative fiction]] [[author]]s. It is also the title of a short story by Joanne Harris, published in March 2005 in her collection ''Jigs & Reels.''
==Stories== The collection contains the following stories: *''The Glass Woman'' by Kaaron Warren *''Quest Soup'' by Donna Maree Hanson *''Li Kao's Adversity Dumplings'' by Zara Baxter *''Blobs'' by Robbie Matthews *''A Man Needs Meat'' by Nicole R Murphy *''Inquisition'' by Mik Bennett *''Kali Dal'' by Stuart and Jenny Barrow *''The Sisters Of Guilin'' by Valerie Y L Toh *''References'' by Geoff Byng *''Stu's Stew'' by Gillian Polack *''Not Like It Used To Be'' by Barbara Robson *''Does the Spearmint Lose Its Flavour on the Bedpost Overnight?'' by Maxine McArthur *''The Spice Merchant'' by Kylie Seluka *''Killer Pie'' by Allan Price *''The Sacred Marcellan Tart'' by T L Miller *''Yes, Virginia'' by Conor Bendle *''La Fée Vert'' by Cameron Hill *''Made from Real Blue Pixies'' by Tessa Kum *''Dead Gods'' by Peter Raftos *''Skeleton Tea'' by Lily Chrywenstrom
==Recipes== The collection contains the following recipes: *''Cookies: Soft, Fat, Ginger'' by Stuart Barrow *''Prawn and Tomato Soup'' by Kaaron Warren *''Pea Soup'' by Donna Maree Hanson *''Li Kao's Adversity Dumplings'' by Zara Baxter *''Pikelets'' by Robbie Matthews *''Mushroom Sandwich'' by Nicole R Murphy *''Burritos'' by Mik Bennett *''Kali Dal'' by Stuart and Jenny Barrow *''Precious Eggs in Rice Nest'' by Valerie Y L Toh *''Dragon and Dog Thistle Congee with Preserved Egg'' by Geoff Byng *''Stu's Stew'' by Gillian Polack *''Damsels in Distress & Fire Spice Paste'' by Barbara Robson *''Bubblegum Icecream'' by Maxine McArthur *''Cinnamon Balls'' by Kylie Seluka *''Chocolate Meringue Pie'' by Allan Price *''Grasshopper Pie'' by T L Miller *''Fairy Bread'' by Conor Bendle *''Absinthe'' by Cameron Hill *''Blue Pixie Margarita'' by Tessa Kum *''Spanish Chocolate'' by Peter Raftos *''Inspiration Tea'' by Lily Chrywenstrom
The stories are illustrated by Brian Smith, Mik Bennett, Tony Flowers, and Ian McHugh. The cover art is by Les Petersen.
==See also== {{portal|Novels}} *''[[Nor of Human]]'' *''[[Machinations: An Anthology of Ingenious Designs]]'' *''[[Elsewhere (Anthology)|Elsewhere]]'' *''[[Encounters (anthology)|Encounters]]'' *''[[The Outcast (Anthology)|The Outcast]]'' *''[[The Grinding House]]''
==External links== *[http://www.csfg.org.au/ CSFG home page] *[http://www.maxinemcarthur.com/ Maxine McArthur home page] *[http://www.lespetersen.com.au/ Les Petersen home page] *[http://www.asif.dreamhosters.com/doku.php?id=gastronomicon/ Review of Gastronomicon on ASif!]
==Bibliography== *Stuart Barrow (ed.), ''Gastronomicon'', (Canberra: Canberra Speculative Fiction Guild, 2005) {{ISBN|0-9581390-4-0}}
[[Category:2005 books]] [[Category:Fiction anthologies]] [[Category:Cookbooks]] [[Category:Books about food and drink]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6beta2)
revision.text:
{{coord|40.67290|-73.99712|type:landmark_globe:earth_region:US-NY|display=title}} The '''Gowanus Memorial Artyard''' was a non-profit,<ref name="cultureinside">{{cite news|url=http://www.cultureinside.com/homeen/blog.aspx/Member/yellowcat/ViewBlog/105/|title=Frank Shifreen currently in a show at Harvard called: Speech Acts|last=Team|first=CI.|date=|publisher=''Culture Inside''|accessdate=2010-12-01|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708213054/http://www.cultureinside.com/homeen/blog.aspx/Member/yellowcat/ViewBlog/105/|archivedate=2011-07-08|df=}}</ref> artist-organized group that organized massive outdoor and indoor [[art exhibition]]s in [[Gowanus, Brooklyn|Gowanus]], [[Brooklyn]] in [[New York City]] in the early 1980s.<ref name="gowanus">{{cite news|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JeQCAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA62&ots=GuHrfTcfwb&dq=Gowanus%20Guerrillas%20new%20york%20magazine&pg=PA62#v=onepage&q=Gowanus%20Guerrillas%20new%20york%20magazine&f=false|title=Gowanus Guerrillas|last=Larson|first=Kay|date=June 8, 1981|publisher=''[[New York Magazine]]'', Vol. 14, No. 23, page 62|accessdate=2010-10-25}}</ref> Founded by artists and curators Michael Keene, [[Frank Shifreen]], and George Moore,<ref name="galleryview">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/03/arts/gallery-view-drawing-a-bead-on-public-monuments.html|title=Gallery View; Drawing A Bead On Public Monuments|last=Glueck|first=Grace|date=October 3, 1982|publisher=''[[New York Times]]''|accessdate=2010-11-30}}</ref> the shows featured monumental sculpture parks next to the [[Gowanus Canal]].<ref name="abcnorio">{{cite news|url=http://www.abcnorio.org/about/history/abc_of_abc.html|title='The ABCs of ABC No Rio And Its Times' - An Introduction by Alan Moore and Marc Miller|last=Moore |first=Alan|year=1985|publisher=[[ABC No Rio]] - The Culture of Opposition Since 1980|accessdate=2010-12-01}}</ref> The two major shows attracted thousands of visitors during their brief runs in 1981 and 1982. The participants artists such as [[Carl Andre]], [[Andy Warhol]]-sponsored [[Keith Haring]],<ref name="digitalmuseum">{{cite news|url=http://www.thedigitalmuseum.org/|title=The Digital Museum|last=|first=|date=|publisher=The Digital Museum|accessdate=2010-12-01}}</ref><ref name="book">{{cite book| last = Vitali| first = Julius|title=The Fine Artists Guide to Marketing and Self Promotion|publisher=[[Allworth Press]], New York | series = 1st edition, page 83 | year = 2003 | isbn = 978-1-58115-281-4}}</ref> [[Christo]], [[Linda and Terry Jamison]], [[Vito Acconci]], [[Nancy Holt]], [[John Fekner]], the controversial [[Chris Burden]], sculptor [[James Nickel]],<ref name="jamesnickel">{{cite news|url=http://www.sculpture.org/portfolio/sculptorPage.php?sculptor_id=1003542|title=James Nickel|publisher=[[International Sculpture Center]]|accessdate=2010-12-01}}</ref> and [[Fred Wilson (artist)|Fred Wilson]].<ref name="wilson">{{cite news|url=http://www.renabranstengallery.com/Bio_WilsonF.html |title=Fred Wilson |publisher=Rena Bransten Gallery |accessdate=2010-12-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604235341/http://www.renabranstengallery.com/Bio_WilsonF.html |archivedate=2011-06-04 |df= }}</ref>
==Group founding== {{Css Image Crop |Image = Gowanus Canal Map.jpg |bSize = 1100 |cWidth = 230 |cHeight = 230 |oTop = 150 |oLeft = 520 |Location = right |Description = The outside Artyard, in the center is the empty block on the left side of the [[Gowanus Canal]] (blue line), directly above the large building adjacent to 9th Street (bottom center), and west of the [[IND Culver Line]] viaduct (red line). }} In 1979 [[Frank Shifreen]], a recent art graduate of [[Pratt Institute]], began hosting open-studio party art shows at his [[Brooklyn, New York]] studio apartment. There a variety of local New York artists began to network.<ref name="gowanus"/> His building, which was a nineteenth-century [[munitions]] factory at 230 3rd Street<ref name="onceupontime">{{cite news |url=http://pardonmeforasking.blogspot.com/2007/10/once-upon-time-on-shores-of-gowan-us.html |title=Once Upon a Time on the Shores of the Gowanus: Frank Shifreen and "The Monument Redefined" Show |last= |first= |date=October 16, 2007 |publisher= |accessdate=2010-11-30}}</ref> in [[Gowanus, Brooklyn]], had over 9,500 square feet, much of it un-rented. Shifreen asked his landlord to periodically use the un-rented space. The building was right next to the extremely polluted [[Gowanus Canal]], was also just two blocks from a five-acre abandoned dump that had been classified as a city-owned "[[Urban open space|Public Site]]". At Smith Street and 5th Street, it was filled with weeds, trash middens, and expired auto bodies.<ref name="galleryview"/>
==''The Monumental Show'' (1981)== Shifreen teamed up with artists Michael Keene and George Moore to plan an art exhibition using both the empty space in the munitions factory and the public space next door. They enlisted help from the Gowanus Canal Community Development Corporation and Carroll Gardens Association,<ref name="onceupontime"/> also receiving a $1500 grant from the Brooklyn Council on the Arts.<ref name="galleryview"/>
Calling themselves the Gowanus Canal Memorial Artyard, they began wheatposting posters throughout the city six months before the show, calling it ''The Monumental Show''. The black-and-white posters were a call for entries, and they received thousands of proposals for live rock music performance and art installations. The organizers selected 150 artists who were each given a 20 by 20 foot space to create their art. The theme of the exhibition was [[monumental sculpture|monumental art]], which consisted of paintings, sculptures, mixed media, and anything one-and-a-half times normal size.<ref name="galleryview"/> The participants included new talent, as well as established artists such as [[Carl Andre]] and [[Andy Warhol]]-sponsored [[Keith Haring]].<ref name="digitalmuseum"/><ref name="book"/>
===Reception=== The show opened on May 16, 1981, and more than 4000 people visited just that first weekend to see the art and hear live music.<ref name="gowanus"/><ref name="digitalmuseum"/><ref name="book"/> As a result of the show, Shifreen's landlord had him arrested for allegedly stealing electricity, and the ensuing controversy increased the press the show was already receiving. On June 8, 1981, ''[[New York Magazine]]'' did an article on the show entitled "Gowanus Guerrillas", calling it "the event of the season."<ref name="gowanus"/> On June 15, 1981, the show made the cover of the ''[[New York Daily News]]''.<ref name="frankling">{{cite news |url=http://www.franklinfurnace.org/goings_on/goings_on/03_06_12.html#shifreen |title=Frank Shifreen, FF Alumn, art against war, exhibitions and websites. |last=Spiller |first=Harley |date=June 12, 2003 |publisher=Franklin Furnace Archive, Inc. |accessdate=2010-12-01}}</ref>
===Controversy=== One artist, the young Laura Foreman, contributed an installation she called "Roomwork" to the interior of the munitions factory. However, Shifreen's landlord, the police, and then reportedly violent local members of the [[Jewish Defense League]] took offense to her exhibit's inclusion of a painting of [[Hitler]]. A few days after the opening, members of the Jewish Defense League entered the exhibit and slashed another painting by [[Komar and Melamid]], the show closing down soon after.<ref name="hankonealphoto">{{cite news |url=http://www.hankonealphoto.com/blog/2010/07/25/128-komar-and-melamid-.html |title=Komar and Melamid |last=O'neal |first=Hank |date=July 26, 2010 |publisher= |accessdate=2010-12-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111004195130/http://www.hankonealphoto.com/blog/2010/07/25/128-komar-and-melamid-.html |archivedate=October 4, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
==''The Monument Redefined'' (1982)== [[File:MonumentRedefined.jpg|thumb|220px|Poster seen around New York]] After the success of the first, Shifreen and artist Scott Siken began organizing a second show.<ref name="galleryview"/> Entitled ''The Monument Redefined'', the 1982 show was held in three locations. The outdoor site covered twelve acres with artwork visible from the window of Brooklyn's [[F (New York City Subway service)|F subway]].<ref name="digitalmuseum"/><ref name="rhizome">{{cite news|url=http://rhizome.org/profile.php?1057286|title=Frank Shifreen|last=|first=|date=|publisher=Rhizome|accessdate=2010-12-01|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101220082003/http://rhizome.org/profile.php?1057286|archivedate=2010-12-20|df=}}</ref> The space for the two indoor sites was donated by the Downtown Brooklyn Cultural Center, while sponsors included the [[New York City Department of Parks and Recreation|Department of Parks and Recreation]], the Decentralization Program of the [[New York State Council on the Arts]],<ref name="galleryview"/> The City of New York, [[Con Edison]], the [[F.W. Woolworth Company]], and the Organization of Independent Artists.<ref name="digitalmuseum"/>
The stated theme of the exhibition was not size, but social responsibility.<ref name="digitalmuseum"/> The call-for-entries was again a poster, but also free ads from ''[[Artforum]]'', ''Arts'', and ''[[Artnews]]'', and thousands of artists submitted entrees. The co-curators selected 400 proposals, including works by well-known artists such as [[Carl Andre]], [[Christo]], [[Vito Acconci]], [[Nancy Holt]], the controversial [[Chris Burden]], [[Dennis Oppenheim]], [[Nancy Spero]], [[Leon Golub]], [[Boaz Vaadia]],<ref name="galleryview"/> TODT,<ref name="fleischer">{{cite news |url=http://www.fleisher-ollmangallery.com/artists.php?id=28&page=2 |title=Artists: TODT |last= |first= |date= |publisher=Fleisher Ollman Gallery |accessdate=2010-12-01}}</ref> sculptor [[James Nickel]],<ref name="jamesnickel"/> and [[Fred Wilson (artist)|Fred Wilson]].<ref name="wilson"/> Some of the co-jurors were [[Marcia Tucker]], the director of the New Museum, [[Henry Geldzahler]], the New York City Cultural Commissioner, and [[Mary Boone]], the gallery owner.<ref name="galleryview"/>
===Reception=== As before, the show was a success, with multiple art publications publishing reviews. Three panel discussions were held at [[Cooper Union]], and artists as well as art critics took part.<ref name="digitalmuseum"/> On October 3, 1982, there was a review in ''[[The New York Times]]''.<ref name="galleryview"/>
==''Gowanus Canal Redefined'' (1982)==
''The Monument Redefined'' was welcomed by much of the local [[Gowanus, Brooklyn]] community.<ref name="galleryview"/> Buddy Scotto and James Albano of the Gowanus Community Development Program contacted the Gowanus Memorial Artyard to offer a sponsorship for an architectural competition.<ref name="onceupontime"/> Called ''The Gowanus Canal Redefined'', it was one of the only grassroots contests of its kind.<ref name="onceupontime"/> Frank Shifreen and Scott Siken of the Gowanus Memorial Artyard organized and curated the event, selecting proposals for "critical reinterpretations" of the [[Gowanus Canal]]. A $1000 prize was to be awarded to the best architectural proposal for revitalizing the Gowanus Canal area.<ref name="galleryview"/> The area, a former industrial zone, was suffering from extreme neglect in the early 1980s.<ref name="storefront">{{cite news |url=http://www.storefrontnews.org/archive/all?y=0&m=0&p=17&c=1&e=378 |title=Archive of Exhibitions: Gowanus Canal Redefined |last= |first= |date= |publisher=[[Storefront for Art and Architecture]] |accessdate=2010-12-01}}</ref> The Canal running through the area is currently dubbed a [[Super fund]] site.<ref name="grosscanal">{{cite news |url=http://nymag.com/news/intelligencer/topic/57886/ |title=A Brief History of the Gowanus Canal |last=Bonanos |first=Christopher |date=July 12, 2009 |publisher=''[[New York Magazine]]'' |accessdate=2010-12-01}}</ref> The area's seawater canal, open park spaces, and close proximity to [[Manhattan]] and public transportation were requested to be incorporated into the proposal designs.
The show ran from October 18, 1982 to October 29, 1982 and included participants Todd Ayoung, Dennis Joyce, Stephen Korns, Joe Lewis, Brian McMahon, and Kristin Steen.<ref name="storefront"/>
==Historical significance== The show was one of several mega-shows in the early 1980s.<ref name="collaborativeprojects">{{cite news |url=http://collaborativeprojectsarchive.wikispaces.com/A+brief+history+of+the+MWF+Video+Club. |title=A Brief History of the MWF Video Club |last=Moore |first=Alan |date=July 2003 |publisher=Collaborative Projects Inc. |accessdate=2010-12-01}}</ref> Before the show, the public ''Times Square Show'' exhibition had nightly art performances every night for months, and in the two years after that there were several large-scale exhibitions in disused buildings in public locations. One was ''Ninth Street Survival'' at an abandoned school on the [[Lower East Side, Manhattan|Lower East Side]] of [[Manhattan]], as well as the ''Coney Island Show''<ref name="collaborativeprojects"/> on a pier at the [[Coney Island]] Amusement Park.<ref name="abcnorio"/> Several New York artists, including Shifreen and Julius Vitali, have theorized that the [[East Village, Manhattan]] art movement in the 1980s may have resulted partly from the artist-organized and not-for-profit shows of the early 1980s, including ''The Monumental Show'' and ''Monument Redefined''. The shows made it possible for [[art galleries]] and [[art dealers]] to find and support emerging artists.<ref name="digitalmuseum"/><ref name="book"/>
==See also== *[[Monumental sculpture]] *[[Public art]]
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== *[https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/03/arts/gallery-view-drawing-a-bead-on-public-monuments.html October 3, 1982] - article in ''[[The New York Times]]'' *[http://www.storefrontnews.org/archive/all?y=0&m=0&p=17&c=1&e=378 Archive of Exhibitions: ''Gowanus Canal Redefined'']
[[Category:Culture of New York City]] [[Category:Culture of Brooklyn]] [[Category:DIY culture]] [[Category:Underground culture]] [[Category:Modernist sculpture]] [[Category:American art]] [[Category:Art in New York City]] [[Category:Monuments and memorials in New York City]] [[Category:Outdoor sculptures in New York City]] [[Category:Sculpture exhibitions]] [[Category:Art exhibitions in the United States]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Brooklyn]] [[Category:Gowanus, Brooklyn]]

revision.text:
The '''Gypsy Robe''' is a tradition in which a chorus member with the most Broadway credits receives a robe on the opening night of a [[Broadway theatre|Broadway musical]]. The title of the robe was changed to the '''Legacy Robe''' in July 2018.<ref name=legacy>[https://www.americantheatre.org/2018/07/13/actors-equitys-new-name-for-the-gypsy-robe-the-legacy-robe/ "Actors’ Equity’s New Name for the Gypsy Robe: The ‘Legacy Robe’"] ''American Theatre'', July 13, 2018</ref>
== Ritual == Before curtain on the opening night of a [[Broadway theatre|Broadway musical]], actors, stage managers, crew, and everyone associated with the play gather onstage for the Gypsy Robe ceremony. At the center of the stage will be a representative of [[Actors' Equity Association]] and a recently honored gypsy. The honored gypsy wears the robe that's decorated with mementos and drawings from past shows. The Equity representative tells the history of the ritual and announces the newest recipient from the company. The new recipient puts on the robe, and circles the stage counter-clockwise three times as everyone touches the robe for good luck. The Gypsy Robe recipient then makes their way throughout the theatre to continue bringing good luck.<ref>[http://www.actorsequity.org/aboutequity/gypsyrobe/gypsyrobehome.asp "Gypsy Robe"] actorsequity.org</ref> <ref>Pincus-Roth, Zachary. [http://www.playbill.com/features/article/113564-ASK-PLAYBILLCOM-The-Gypsy-Robe "Ask Playbill. The Gypsy Robe"] Playbill, December 13, 2007</ref>
== Rules of the Ritual== According to [[Actors' Equity Association]], the following are the rules of the Gypsy Robe:<ref>[http://www.actorsequity.org/aboutequity/gypsyrobe/gypsyrules.asp "Gypsy Rules"] actorsequity.org</ref> # The Gypsy Robe goes only to Broadway musicals with a chorus. # Robe goes to a chorus member only, with the most number of Broadway chorus credits. # It must be delivered by 1/2 hour on opening night to the member selected. # New recipient must put on Robe and circle the stage 3 times, while cast members reach out and touch Robe for good luck; new recipient visits each dressing room while wearing the Robe. # New recipient supervises the addition of an application from that show to the Robe. Important rules for adding mementos: For wearability, durability, and longevity, add-ons must be lightweight, sturdy, and reasonably sized so each Robe can represent a full season. # Opening night date and the recipient's name are written on or near the memento and cast members are to sign only that section of Robe. # Recipient will attend the next Broadway musical opening and will present the Robe to the next "Gypsy" in that show.
== History == The ritual dates to 1950, when Florence Baum, a chorus member in [[Gentlemen Prefer Blondes (musical)|''Gentlemen Prefer Blondes'']], entered the men's dressing room wearing a robe, pale pink with white feathers.<ref name=NYT>[https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/21/theater/bill-bradley-73-created-the-gypsy-robe.html "Gypsy Robe"] ''The New York Times'', February 20, 2008</ref><ref>[http://broadwayworld.com/article/CBS-SUNDAY-MORNING-to-Feature-Segment-on-Broadway-Gypsy-Robe-610-20120609 "CBS Sunday Morning features segment on Broadway Gypsy Robe"] Broadway World.com</ref> The men took turns trying it on. Fellow chorus member, Bill Bradley, sent a dressing gown from one of his fellow performers to his friend performing in ''[[Call Me Madam]]''. A feathered rose from [[Ethel Merman|Ethel Merman's]] costume was attached to the robe, and it was then given to a chorus member in ''[[Guys and Dolls (musical)|Guys and Dolls]]''.<ref name=NYT/> The robe continued to be passed from one show to another, each time with a memento added on.
The ritual has become more formal, with rules about how it is presented, worn, and displayed. When robes are full of artifacts, a new robe is started. Retired robes are kept at the [[New York Public Library for the Performing Arts]], at the [[Smithsonian]], and at [[Actors' Equity]].
In 2005, Brynn Williams from the Broadway cast of ''In My Life'' became the youngest recipient of the Gypsy Robe at age 12.
On April 18, 2018, Actors Equity announced that the name of robe would be changed at the end of the current theater season. A poll was opened to union members to vote on a new name.<ref>McPhee, Ryan. [http://www.playbill.com/article/actors-equitys-gypsy-robe-will-get-a-new-name "Actors’ Equity’s ‘Gypsy Robe’ Will Get a New Name"] Playbill, April 18, 2018</ref><ref>Fujishima, Kenji. [https://www.theatermania.com/broadway/news/actors-equity-gypsy-robe-name-retired_84864.html "Actors' Equity to Retire "Gypsy Robe" Name at the End of the Season"] theatermania.com, April 18, 2018</ref> The new name chosen is the "Legacy Robe"; the first Legacy Robe presentation took place on July 26, 2018, during the musical ''Head Over Heels''.<ref name=legacy/>
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [https://www.actorsequity.org/aboutequity/awards/Robe/ Gypsy Robe] at the [[Actors' Equity]] Web site—background on "gypsies" and the Gypsy Robe * [http://citylore.org//wp-content/uploads/pdf/gypsy.pdf Broadway's Gypsy Robe] at City Lore * [https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/21/theater/bill-bradley-73-created-the-gypsy-robe.html Bill Bradley obituary], New York Times * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120611032817/http://www.cbsnews.com/video/watch/?id=7411210n The Gypsy Robe], CBS Sunday Morning *[http://www.actorsequity.org/AboutEquity/GypsyRobe/gypsyrecipients.asp "Robes & Recipients" actorsequity.org]
{{Gentlemen Prefer Blondes}}

revision.text:
{{Jewish culture}} The [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] word for symbol is ''ot'', which, in early Judaism, denoted not only a sign, but also a visible religious token of the relation between [[God]] and man. [[File:Magen David Adom.svg|thumb|Magen David Adom]]
==Common iconography== {|class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="3" style="text-align: center;" |Ancient |- ! style="width:10%;"|Symbol ! style="width:10%;"|Image ! style="width:80%;"|History and usage |- |[[Menorah (Temple)|Menorah]] |[[File:Menora.svg|100px]] |Represents the [[Temple in Jerusalem]]. Appears in the [[Emblem of Israel]]. |- |[[Four species|Four Species]] |[[File:Arbaat haminim2.jpg|100px]] |Represents the festival of [[Sukkot]]. Often an accompaniment of the Menorah. |- |[[Shofar]] |[[File:YAD BEN ZVI VIEW 2 20120912 151825.jpg|100px]] |Represents the [[High Holy Days]]. Often an accompaniment of the Menorah. |- ! colspan="3" style="text-align: center;" |Intermediate |- ! style="width:10%;"|Symbol ! style="width:10%;"|Image ! style="width:80%;"|History and usage |- |[[Star of David]] |[[File:Star of David.svg|100px]] |The Star of David, a symbol of Judaism, as a [[religion]], and of the Jewish people as a whole. And it also thought to be the shield (or at least the emblem on it) of King David.
Jewish lore links the symbol to the "[[Seal of Solomon]]", the magical signet ring used by [[King Solomon]] to control demons and spirits. Jewish lore also links the symbol to a magic shield owned by King David that protected him from enemies. Following [[Jewish emancipation]] after the [[French revolution]], Jewish communities chose the Star of David as their symbol. The star is found on the [[Flag of Israel]]. |- |[[Shin (letter)|Shin]] |[[File:Hebrew shin.png|100px]] |Symbolizes [[El Shaddai]] (conventionally translated "God Almighty"), one of the [[Names and Titles of God in Judaism|Names of God in Judaism]]. This symbol is depicted on the ritual objects [[mezuzah]] and [[tefillin]], and in the hand gesture of the [[Priestly Blessing]]. |- |[[Tablets of Stone]] |[[File:Lukhot Habrit.svg|100px]] | |- |[[Lion of Judah]] |[[File:Mosav zkenim 003.jpg|100px]] |The Tanakh compares the tribes of [[Tribe of Judah|Judah]] and Dan to [[lion]]s: "Judah is a lion's whelp."<ref>[[Book of Genesis]] 49:9</ref>
Often a pair of lions appear as heraldic [[supporter]]s, especially of the Tablets of Law. |- ! colspan="3" style="text-align: center;" |Modern |- ! style="width:10%;"|Symbol ! style="width:10%;"|Image ! style="width:80%;"|History and usage |- |[[Chai (symbol)]] |[[File:Hebrew Chai Symbol.svg|100px]] | |- |[[Hamsa]] |[[File:Hamsa.jpg|100px]] | |- |}
==Shabbat and circumcision== {{Judaism}} The Shabbat, according to Ezekiel 20:12 is God's sign ("ot") between Him and His people. It states, "Moreover also I gave them my shabbats, to be a sign between me and them, that they might know that I am the LORD that sanctify them." The Shabbat was instituted on the seventh day of creation for all mankind, and God did three things as our example in Genesis 2:1-3... 1) He rested from all work, 2) He blessed the Shabbat, and 3) God sanctified the seventh day, which means He set it apart for only Holy use. The ten commandments in Exodus 20:8-12 explain further that, "six days shall you labor and do all your work, but the seventh day is the Shabbat of the Lord your God, in that day you shall do no work".
==The Tabernacle and the sacrifices==
{{Main|Tabernacle (Judaism)|Korban}}
According to the [[Hebrew Bible]], while the [[Israelites]] were living in the [[Sinai Peninsula|Sinai]] for forty years, they built a Tabernacle ({{lang-he|משכן}} [[transliteration|translit]]: ''mishkan'', "Place of [Divine] dwelling"); this was viewed as the abode of the Shekhinah (the presence of YHWH) on Earth, and the place where the priests could minister to God on behalf of the nation of Israel.
==The priests== The Hebrew for priest is ''Kohen''; the ''Kohanim'' (plural) mediated between God and man by offering sacrifices, and by other services in the Temple. The leader of them the ''Kohen Gadol'', the high priest.
The vestments of the high priest were interpreted in three ways. The explanation of Philo is as follows ("Vita Mosis," iii. 209): His upper garment was the symbol of the ether, while the blossoms represented the earth, the [[pomegranate]]s typified running water, and the [[bell (instrument)|bell]]s denoted the music of the water. The [[ephod]] corresponded to heaven, and the stones on both shoulders to the two hemispheres, one above and the other below the earth. The six names on each of the stones were the six signs of the [[zodiac]], which were denoted also by the twelve names on [[Priestly breastplate|the breastplate]]. The miter was the sign of the crown, which exalted the high priest above all earthly kings.
[[Josephus]]' explanation is this:<ref>"Ant." iii. 7, § 7</ref> The coat was the symbol of the earth, the upper garment emblemized heaven, while the bells and pomegranates represented thunder and lightning. The [[ephod]] typified the four elements, and the interwoven gold denoted the glory of God. The breastplate was in the center of the ephod, as the earth formed the center of the universe; the [[girdle]] symbolized the ocean, the stones on the shoulders the sun and moon, and the jewels in the breastplate the twelve signs of the zodiac, while the miter was a token of heaven.
The [[Talmud|Jerusalem Talmud]]<ref>Menachot vii. 1</ref> and [[Midrash]] ''Leviticus Rabbah'' (x.) give the following interpretation: The coat symbolized atonement for murder or for the sin of wearing mixed garments, and the undergarment typified atonement for unchastity. The miter denoted atonement for pride, and the belt for theft or trickery. The breastplate represented atonement for any perversion of the Law, the ephod for idolatry, and the robe for slander.
==The symbolic values of numbers== {{See also|Significance of numbers of Judaism|Hebrew numerology}}
The number [[3 (number)|three]] was the symbol of holiness and love. The Holy of Holies occupied one-third, and the Holy Place two-thirds, of the entire Temple. The tapestries were ten times three [[ell]]s in length, and there were three vessels each for the altar of burnt offering, the altar of incense, and the Ark. The candlestick had twice three arms (besides the shaft, which also held a lamp), and each arm had three knobs. The blessing of the priest consisted of three sections,<ref>Num. vi. 24, 25</ref> and in the invocation of God the word "holy" was repeated thrice.
The symbolism of the number [[4 (number)|four]] was based on the contemplation of the quaternity as found in the universe, which included both heaven and earth<ref>comp. Job xxxvii. I Copied from wikipedia3; Isa. xi. 12; Ezek. vii. 2; I Chron. ix. 24; Dan. viii. 8.</ref> The number four connoted [[heaven]] as the throne of God.
The Holy of Holies was in the form of a [[Cube (geometry)|cube]], and the Holy Place was a double cube in length. All the vessels of the Temple in Jerusalem (except the candlestick) were rectangular. According to Ezekiel i. 26-28, the number four symbolized the divine revelation, while in the view of Philo it was the number of complete harmony.<ref>"De Opificio Mundi," pp. 13–15</ref>
The number [[5 (number)|five]] typified semicompletion. The dimensions of the curtain of the Holy of Holies were four ells by five; the altar in the court covered a surface of five square ells; and there were five pillars at the entrance to the Tabernacle.
The number [[6 (number)|six]] symbolizes imperfection.
The number [[7 (number)|seven]] was the general symbol for all association with God, and was the favorite religious number of Judaism, typifying the covenant of holiness and sanctification, and also all that was holy and sanctifying in purpose. The candlestick had seven lamps, and the acts of atonement and purification were accompanied by a sevenfold sprinkling. The establishment of the Sabbath, the [[shmita|Sabbatical year]], and the year of jubilee was based on the number seven, as were the periods of purification and of mourning. The number 7 is the Divine number of completion.
The number [[8 (number)|eight]] symbolizes new beginnings. According to [[Kaballah]] in the [[Zohar]] the number eight signifies this because the eighth day was the first day after creation when God returned to work; the week began again.
The number [[10 (number)|ten]] symbolized absolute completeness. The court to the Tabernacle was ten times ten ells long, and five times ten ells wide, and in the Holy of Holies the [[Ten Commandments]] were preserved.
The number [[12 (number)|twelve]], being the product of three and four, typified the union of the people with God.<ref name="Maude-1862">[[#MAUDE 1862|Maude 1862]]: p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=8oMEAAAAQAAJ&dq=%22union%20of%20the%20people%20with%20god%22%20israel&pg=PA509#v=onepage&q=%22union%20of%20the%20people%20with%20god%22%20israel&f=false 509]</ref><ref>{{Bibleverse|1|Kings|18:31-38|NIV}}</ref><ref>{{Bibleverse||Genesis|32:24-30|NIV}}</ref> On the table were twelve loaves of show-bread, and the breastplate of the priest contained twelve precious stones as emblems of the [[twelve tribes of Israel]], which camped round about the Sanctuary.
The number [[13 (number)|thirteen]] symbolizes the principles of faith and God's mercy.
The number [[18 (number)|eighteen]] is considered significant because the [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] word for "life" is חי (''[[Chai (symbol)|chai]]''), which has a [[gematria|numerical value]] of 18.
The number [[26 (number)|twenty six]] symbolizes God's name.
==Metals and minerals== [[Gold]] was the symbol of the divine or celestial light, the glory of God.<ref>Zech. vi. 11; Dan. xi. 21</ref> [[Silver]] was the emblem of moral innocence and of holiness.<ref>Isa. i. 22; Jer. vi. 30</ref> [[Brass]] symbolized hardness, strength, and firmness.<ref>Lev. xxvi. 19; Jer. xv. 12; Job xl. 18</ref> Brass was a substitute for gold, and iron for silver.<ref>Isa. lx. 17</ref>
[[Salt]] was declared to be necessary in every meal-offering, in which it takes the place of the blood in the animal sacrifices.<ref>Lev. ii. 13; but comp. Ezek. xliii. 24</ref> In the Talmud salt symbolizes the [[Torah]], for as the world cannot exist without salt, so it can not endure without the Torah.<ref>Soferim xv. 8</ref>
==Colors==
The Israelites used an [[indigo]]-colored dye called ''tekhelet''; this dye was likely made from snail ''[[murex trunculus]]''. This dye was very important in both Jewish and non-Jewish cultures of this time, and was used by royalty and the upper-class in dyeing their clothing, sheets, curtains, etc. This dye is known as [[Tyrian purple]].
In the Torah the Israelites are commanded to dye one of the threads of their [[tallit]] (prayer shawl) with tekhelet; when they look at this dye they will think of the blue sky, and of the God above them in Heaven. Tekhelet corresponds to the color of the divine revelation (Midrash Numbers Rabbah xv.) [[Blue in Judaism]] has thus had an important significance throughout the history of Jewish culture up to the present. Blue was also associated with the ten commandments. When Moses and the elders went up the mount Sinai, they saw God standing on a Sapphire pavement (Blue) and the tables of the law were made of THE stone (i.e. Sapphire) and thus the blue on their garments was to be a permanent reminder of the law of God.
"Argaman" was the symbol of power, and of glory,<ref>Isa. lx. 6; Judges viii. 26</ref> so that [[Alexander Balas]] robed Jonathan in purple,<ref>I Macc. x. 20</ref> which was especially used to designate royal dignity.<ref>I Macc. x. 20, xi. 58</ref>
"Tola'at" and "shani" ("[[scarlet (color)|scarlet]]," "[[crimson]]") symbolized blood, and thus frequently typified life, although this color often designated sin, as well as joy and happiness.<ref>Gen. xxxviii. 28; Josh. ii. 18, 21; Jer. iv. 30</ref>
Purification from sin was also symbolized by purple.<ref>Lev. xvi. 10</ref>
"Shesh" ([[white]]) was the symbol of physical and intellectual purity, being the true color of light, without any modification.<ref>Cant. v. 10; Dan. iv. 10, 14, 20; Zech. xiv. 5</ref> White also symbolizes death. In some cases, it can also symbolize life.
Yellow has an association with an anti-Semitic forced identification mark (see [[Yellow badge]]).
==Festivals and holy days== [[File:2nd century Rome gold goblet shows Jewish ritual objects.jpg|thumb|Jewish ritual objects shown on a gold goblet (2nd century CE) excavated in Rome]] The Torah delineates three [[pilgrimage]] festivals, [[Passover]], [[Shavuot]] (The Feasts of Weeks) and [[Sukkot]] (Tabernacles). Each of these was tied to the agricultural cycle of the Israelites, and was also given a theological symbolism.
[[Passover]] celebrated the rebirth of nature, and symbolized the origin of the Jewish people.
The eating of bitter herbs symbolized the miseries of the [[The Exodus#Bondage in Egypt|Egyptian bondage]]. In the evenings four cups of wine were drunk, to symbolize the four world-kingdoms.<ref>Talmud Yerushalmi Pesachim 37c; Midrash Gen. Rabbah lxxx</ref> People eating during the Passover meal reclined, in the style of free rich aristocrats, to represent their liberation from [[slavery]].
A discussion of the meaning of [[Shavuot]] (the Feast of Weeks) and of [[Sukkot]], the Feast of [[Tabernacle (Judaism)|Tabernacles]], is found in the entries on those subjects.
A discussion of symbolism inherent in [[Rosh Hashanah]] (The New Year) and [[Yom Kippur]] (the Day of Atonement) is found in the entries on those subjects. The Day of Atonement was considered the most holy day of the entire year, and was regarded as the symbol of the complete atonement of the people and of their absolution from their sins committed against God.
==Symbolic visions of the Prophets== [[Jeremiah (prophet)|Jeremiah]] beheld an [[almond]]-tree as a token of the speedy fulfillment of the word of God.
[[Amos (prophet)|Amos]] saw a basket of summer fruit as a symbol of the approaching end of Israel.<ref>Amos viii. 1</ref>
Ahijah the Shilonite tore Jeroboam's mantle into twelve pieces, to typify the division of the kingdom of Israel,<ref>I Kings xi. 30</ref> and Zedekiah made horns of iron to encourage Ahab to engage in war with Ramoth-gilead.<ref>I Kings xxii. 11</ref> King Joash, at the command of the prophet Elisha, shot arrows from the open window into the air, to symbolize the destruction of his enemies.<ref>II Kings xiii. 15-19</ref>
Isaiah walked naked and barefoot to show how the [[Ancient Egypt|Egyptians]] and [[People of Ethiopia|Ethiopians]] would be treated when taken captive by the Assyrians,<ref>Isa. xx. 2</ref> while Jeremiah wore a [[yoke]] upon his neck to induce the nations to submit to the King of Assyria.<ref>Jer. xxvii. 2-4, 10-12</ref>
[[Ezekiel]] was commanded to inscribe the names of certain tribes upon separate pieces of wood, to show that God would reunite those tribes.<ref>Ezek. xxxvii. 15</ref>
[[File:Leningrad Codex Carpet page e.jpg|thumb|The Star of David in the oldest surviving complete copy of the [[Masoretic text]], the [[Leningrad Codex]], dated 1008.]]
==On tombstones== Some common themes appear on many Jewish tombstones. Two hands with outspread fingers indicated that the dead man was descended from priestly stock (''[[Kohen|Kohanim]]'') who blessed the people in this fashion, and a jug was carved on the tombstones of the [[Levite]]s as an emblem of those who washed the priest's hands before he pronounced the blessing.
Some gravestones show a tree with branches either outspread or broken off, symbolizing the death of a young man or an old man respectively; or they have a cluster of [[grape]]s as an emblem of Israel.
The [[Star of David]] (''Magen David'') occurs frequently.
Sometimes figures symbolized the name of the deceased, as the figure of a lion for Loeb, a wolf for Benjamin, and a rose for the name Bluma/Blume.
==Influence on Christian symbols== The influence of Judaism upon [[Christian symbolism]] as early as the 2nd and 3rd centuries A.D., is apparent both in painting and in sculpture, the most frequent motives being those that occur in the [[Mishnah]] as formulas for prayer on fast-days. The prayer beginning with the words "Mi she-'anah," which was included in the [[selihah]] at an early date, was adopted in the Christian ritual as the litany "Libera domine." This litany was figuratively used in a certain sequence as a symbol, for the sacrifice of [[Isaac]] was regarded as a symbol of the [[crucifixion]] of [[Jesus]], since the early religions, and the act of sacrifice emblemized the death on the cross.
Abraham was represented as the symbol of the power of faith and Isaac as the sacrificed redeemer. The ascension of [[Elijah]] was believed to typify the [[ascension of Jesus Christ]], who was regarded by Christian symbolism as an analogue to Elijah, although this ascension was also taken as a type of the general [[resurrection]] from the dead. Job sitting among the ashes was the symbol of patience and of the power of resistance of the flesh; and [[Hananiah, Azariah, and Mishael|Hananiah]], [[Meshach|Mishael]], and [[Abednego|Azariah]] in the fiery furnace typified steadfastness in persecution and faith in the aid of God. Christian [[sarcophagi]] contained artistic representations of the fall of man, [[Noah]] and the ark, scenes from the life of [[Moses]] in three variations, [[Joshua]], [[David]], and [[Daniel (biblical figure)|Daniel]].
==The land of Zion== {{Main|Land of Israel}}
[[Zion]] is a Biblical term that refers to [[Jerusalem]], and is the source for the modern term [[Zionism]].
==See also== * [[Jewish services]] * [[Menorah (Temple)]] * [[Religious symbolism]] * [[Ephod]] * [[United States military chaplain symbols]] (includes history of Jewish Chaplain insignia) * [[Winged sun#Hebrew|Winged sun § Hebrew]] * [[Bar Kochba Revolt coinage]]
== Notes == {{Reflist|2}}
==References== * {{cite book |title=Scripture manners and customs| last=Maude |first=Mary Fawler | authorlink= | editor1-first=| editor1-last= | editor2-first= |editor2-last= |year=1862 |publisher=Society for Promoting Christian Knowledge |location=London |isbn=1-147-04502-X |page=600 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8oMEAAAAQAAJ |accessdate=2010-09-28 |ref=MAUDE_1862}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Jewish symbols}} *''[http://libmma.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/ref/collection/p15324coll10/id/156533 Age of spirituality : late antique and early Christian art, third to seventh century]'' from The Metropolitan Museum of Art * [https://web.archive.org/web/20031114203756/http://www.jhom.com/topics/lions/art.htm Lions in Jewish art] * [http://www.heraldica.org/topics/national/jewish.htm Jewish Heraldry]

revision.text:
{{Infobox writer | name = John Schoenherr | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = John Carl Schoenherr | birth_date = {{birth date|1935|7|5|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[New York City]], New York | death_date = {{death date and age |2010|4|8|1935|7|5|mf=yes}} | death_place = [[Easton, Pennsylvania]], USA | occupation = Illustrator | nationality = American | period = 1958–2007 | genre = [[Science fiction]], [[Children's literature|children's]] [[picture books]] | subject = [[Wildlife]] | notableworks = {{plainlist| * ''[[The Illustrated Dune]]'' * ''[[Owl Moon]]'' }} | awards = {{plainlist| * [[Hugo Award]] (1965) * [[Caldecott Medal]] (1988) }} | spouse = Judith Grey | parents = | children = Ian, Jenny }} '''John Carl Schoenherr''' (July 5, 1935 – April 8, 2010) was an American [[illustrator]]. He won the 1988 [[Caldecott Medal]] for U.S. children's book illustration, recognizing ''Owl Moon'' by [[Jane Yolen]], a father-and-daughter story where only Schoenherr's drawings reveal the child's gender. He was posthumously inducted by the [[Science Fiction and Fantasy Hall of Fame]] in 2015. ==Life== Schoenherr was born in New York City (Manhattan) and raised in [[Queens]], "in a German-speaking household in a polyglot community", where he used drawings to communicate with speakers of other languages. He graduated from [[Stuyvesant High School]],{{cite web |url=http://www.embracingthechild.org/aschoenherr.html |title=Biography – John Schoenherr |website=EmbracingtheChild.org |accessdate=2007-11-02}} and studied art at the [[Art Students League of New York]] with [[Will Barnet]] and at [[Pratt Institute]]. Schoenherr was a resident of [[Delaware Township, Hunterdon County, New Jersey]].{{cite news |last=Adelson |first=Fred B. |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E06E1D9153BF93AA35752C0A9669C8B63 |title=ART; Children's Page Turners to Linger Over |newspaper=The New York Times |date=January 9, 2000 |accessdate=2007-12-09 |quote=
Both Richard Egielski of Milford and John Schoenherr of Delaware Township (near Stockton) are represented by illustrations from books aimed at ages 4 to 8, the youngest group.}} He died on April 8, 2010, of [[chronic obstructive pulmonary disease]] in [[Easton, Pennsylvania]]. ==Career== Schoenherr may be known best as the original illustrator of the dust jacket art of ''[[Dune (novel)|Dune]]'',{{cite web |url=http://omnireboot.com/2013/dune/ |title=''Dune'': The Most Important Science Fiction Art Ever |work=[[Omni Reboot]] |first=Jeff |last=Love |date=August 16, 2013 |accessdate=2014-10-31}} a 1965 science fiction novel by [[Frank Herbert]] that inaugurated a book series and [[Dune (franchise)|media franchise]]. He had previously illustrated the serializations of the novel in ''[[Analog (magazine)|Analog]]'', an endeavor which secured him a 1965 [[Hugo Award]] for Best Professional Artist.{{cite web |url=http://www.thehugoawards.org/hugo-history/1965-hugo-awards/ |title=1965 Hugo Awards |publisher=The Hugo Awards (thehugoawards.org) |accessdate=2014-10-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yVV9vAxG?url=http://www.thehugoawards.org/hugo-history/1965-hugo-awards/ |archivedate=2011-05-07 |df= }} He later did the art for the ''Analog'' serialization of Herbert's ''[[Children of Dune]]''. In 1978 [[Berkley Books]] published ''[[The Illustrated Dune]]'', an edition of ''Dune'' with 33 black-and-white sketch drawings and 8 full color paintings by Schoenherr. Herbert wrote in 1980 that though he had not spoken to Schoenherr prior to the artist creating the paintings, the author was surprised to find that the artwork appeared exactly as he had imagined its fictional subjects, including [[sandworm (Dune)|sandworms]], [[Baron Harkonnen]] and the [[Sardaukar]].{{cite web |last=Herbert|first=Frank|url=http://www.frankherbert.org/news/genesis.html |title=''Dune'' Genesis|accessdate=2014-10-31 |publisher=Reprinted with permission at FrankHerbert.org |work=[[Omni (magazine)|Omni]] |date=July 1980 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120107220342/http://www.frankherbert.org/news/genesis.html |archivedate=2012-01-07}} Schoenherr was also very well known as a wildlife artist and children's book illustrator, with over forty books to his credit. Most of his black-and-white illustration work used the [[scratchboard]] technique, and he was long known as the only [[commercial artist]] who specialized in it. His paintings were often [[egg tempera]], another unusual medium. Schoenherr also completed paintings for [[NASA]].{{cite book |last=DeVore |first=Howard |authorlink=Howard DeVore |title=A History of the Hugo, Nebula and International Fantasy Awards 1951–1986 |location=Dearborn, Michigan |publisher=The Misfit Press |year=1987 |page=18}}{{cite book |last=Miller |first=Ron |authorlink=Ron Miller (artist and author) |title=Space Art: A Starlog Photo Guidebook |location=New York |publisher=Starlog Press |year=1976 |page=179}}{{cite book |last=DiFate |first=Vincent |authorlink=Vincent DiFate |title=DiFate's Catalog of Science Fiction Hardware |location=New York |publisher=Workman Publishers |year=1980}} Schoenherr's knowledge of [[zoology]] was very useful in creating alien creatures. He was a member of the [[American Society of Mammalogists]], the [[Society of Animal Artists]], and the [[Society of Illustrators]]. Beginning in the 1960s, Schoenherr created numerous science fiction illustrations, in addition to artwork in other genres.{{cite book |last=DiFate |first=Vincent |chapter=Science Fiction Art: Some Contemporary Science Fiction Illustrators |title=The Science Fiction Reference Book |editor-first=Marshall B |editor-last=Tymn |location=San Bernardino |publisher=The Borgo Press |year=1981 |page=51}} Among the books he illustrated are ''The Wolfling'' and ''[[Rascal (book)|Rascal]]'' by [[Sterling North]], the latter a [[Newbery Honor Book]]. Under [[John W. Campbell, Jr.]] and [[Ben Bova]] at ''Analog'', he also illustrated the first ''[[Dragonriders of Pern]]'' stories by [[Anne McCaffrey]], the 1967/1968 novellas "Weyr Search" and "Dragonrider" (each featured on one ''Analog'' cover as well) that were subsequently developed as the novel ''[[Dragonflight]]''. Schoenherr's July 1975 cover for ''Analog'' has been cited as influential in the designs for the ''[[Star Wars]]'' character [[Chewbacca]].{{cite web |url=http://binarybonsai.com/2010/09/18/george-lucas-stole-chewbacca-but-its-okay/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130808131550/http://binarybonsai.com/blog/george-lucas-stole-chewbacca-but-its-okay |title=George Lucas stole Chewbacca, but it's Okay |first=Michael |last=Heilemann |date=September 18, 2010 |publisher=Binary Bonsai |archivedate=August 8, 2013 |accessdate=July 17, 2015}} He also worked for paperback and hardcover science fiction publishers like [[Ace Books]] and [[Doubleday (publisher)|Doubleday]]. ==Awards== * 1965 [[Hugo Award]] for Best Professional Artist * 1988 [[Caldecott Medal]] for ''[[Owl Moon]]'' by [[Jane Yolen]] * 2015 [[Science Fiction and Fantasy Hall of Fame]] ==See also== {{Portal bar |Children's literature |Science fiction |Visual arts }} ==References== {{Reflist |25em |refs= {{cite news |title=John Schoenherr, Children's Book Illustrator, Dies at 74 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/15/arts/15schoenherr.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=April 15, 2010 |accessdate=2010-04-15 | first=Margalit | last=Fox}} {{cite news|url=http://www.locusmag.com/News/2015/06/2014-science-fiction-hall-of-fame-inductees-and-fundraiser#sthash.uwR4dGzo.dpuf |title=2015 SF&F Hall of Fame Inductees & James Gunn Fundraiser |date=June 12, 2015 |accessdate=July 17, 2015 |work=[[Locus (magazine)|Locus]]}} [http://www.empmuseum.org/at-the-museum/museum-features/science-fiction-and-fantasy-hall-of-fame/members/john-schoenherr.aspx "John Schoenherr: American illustrator known for his science fiction magazine covers and drawings"]. ''Science Fiction and Fantasy Hall of Fame''. EMP Museum (empmuseum.org). Retrieved 2015-09-10. {{isfdb series|11825|''Dune'' Universe}} {{isfdb series|482|''Dragonriders of Pern''}} }} ==External links== * [http://www.embracingthechild.org/aschoenherr.html John Schoenherr] at Embracing the Child — curriculum vitae * [https://web.archive.org/web/20011006055911/http://www.spanierman.com/schoenherrbio.htm John Schoenherr biography] at Spanierman Gallery (archived 2001-10-06) * {{isfdb name|1393}} * [http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/loom/2010/04/08/in-memory-of-the-great-bear-of-locktown/ "In Memory of the Great Bear of Locktown"] (''Discover'', April 8, 2010) * [http://www.bpib.com/illustra2/schoenherr.html John Schoenherr] at JVJ Classic Illustrator Biographies * {{LCAuth|n79074333|John Schoenherr|48|}} * {{Gutenberg author | id=Schoenherr,+John | name=John Schoenherr}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Schoenher, John}} [[Category:1935 births]] [[Category:2010 deaths]] [[Category:American illustrators]] [[Category:Animal artists]] [[Category:American speculative fiction artists]] [[Category:Caldecott Medal winners]] [[Category:American children's book illustrators]] [[Category:Hugo Award-winning artists]] [[Category:Science fiction artists]] [[Category:Stuyvesant High School alumni]] [[Category:People from Delaware Township, Hunterdon County, New Jersey]]

{{Infobox Artwork | image_file=Courbet - L'Hallali du cerf.jpg | title=''Killing a Deer'' | artist=[[Gustave Courbet]] | year=about 1867 | medium= [[Oil on canvas]] | height_metric= 355 | width_metric=505 | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city=[[Besançon]] | museum=[[Musée des Beaux-Arts et d'archéologie de Besançon|Museum of Fine Arts of Besançon]] }} '''''Killing a Deer''''' or '''''A Deer Hunt - The Kill''''' (''L'Hallali du cerf'' in French), is a very large picture (355 by 505 cm), representing a hunting scene, painted in 1867 by [[Gustave Courbet]]. The picture is currently on display in the [[Musée d'Orsay]] of [[Paris]].
== History == The painting was done during the winter of 1866-1867. It is in the large format newly adopted by Courbet, as also in ''[[A Burial at Ornans]]'' and ''[[The Artist's Studio]]''. The work was exhibited at the [[French art salons and academies]] of 1869. The picture caused some scandal, major formats being previously reserved for noble [[history painting]]s rather than hunting scenes.
== Iconography == The scene shows a deer attacked by a pack of hunting dogs and collapsed on the snowy ground. Two characters are on the right. The drill is Cusenier Jules, a resident of [[Ornans]] while the man on horseback is Felix Gaudy, of [[Vuillafans]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Pinette|first1=Matthieu|last2=Soulier-François|first2=Françoise|title=From Belini to Bonnard: Great Masterpieces|location=Besançon|year=1992|pages=184–185}}</ref> ''L'Hallali'' is in the tradition of representation of the scene [[Hunting|hunt]], from the seventeenth century. Courbet uses a harsh realistic representation closer to Flemish models. Hunting scenes are common in the paintings of Courbet; every step of the chase is represented
== Influences == [[File:Eugène Delacroix - Le Massacre de Scio.jpg|thumb|right|200px|''[[The Massacre at Chios]]'' by [[Eugène Delacroix]] in [[Musée du Louvre|Louvre]].]] There is another influence in this painting, that of ''[[The Massacre at Chios]]'' (1824) by [[Eugène Delacroix]] ''(illustrated)''. His influence is reflected particularly through the mounted character.<ref>{{cite book|last=Robinson|first=Margaret|title=Courbet's Hunt Scenes: The End of a Tradition|location=Providence, Rhode Island|year=1990|pages=1–24}}</ref>
== References == <references />
{{Gustave Courbet}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Kill of Deer}} [[Category:Paintings by Gustave Courbet]] [[Category:1867 paintings]] [[Category:Collections of the Musée des Beaux-Arts et d'archéologie de Besançon|kill of deer]] [[Category:Deer in art]] [[Category:Dogs in art]] [[Category:Horses in art]] [[Category:Hunting in art]] [[Category:Paintings about death]]
